input: Air Algérie Flight 5017 was a scheduled international passenger flight from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, to Algiers, Algeria, which crashed near Gossi, Mali, on 24 July 2014. The McDonnell Douglas MD-83 twinjet with 110 passengers and 6 crew on board, operated by Swiftair for Air Algérie, disappeared from radar about fifty minutes after take-off. There were no survivors. The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), assisting the Malian authorities, published an investigation report in April 2016, concluding that, while the aircraft was cruising on autopilot, ice accretion on the engines caused a reduction of thrust that led to a high-altitude stall. The crew was unable to recover from the stall, and the aircraft crashed to the ground. The BEA issued several recommendations to Air
syn: Air Algérie Flight 5017, a regular international flight from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, to Algiers, Algeria, met disaster near Gossi, Mali, on July 24, 2014. The McDonnell Douglas MD-83 aircraft, carrying 110 passengers and 6 crew members, and operated by Swiftair on behalf of Air Algérie, vanished off radar approximately fifty minutes following departure. All lives were lost. The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), in cooperation with Malian officials, released a report in April 2016, determining that ice buildup on the engines during autopilot led to diminished engine power and resulted in a critical altitude stall. The pilots failed to rectify the stall, causing the plane to plummet. The BEA proposed a number of recommendations to Air Algérie following their findings.

input: Belarus participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with the song "Cheesecake" written by Yuriy Vashchuk and Dmitry Novik. The song was performed by Teo, which is the artistic name of singer Yuriy Vashchuk. The Belarusian entry for the 2014 contest in Copenhagen, Denmark was selected through a national final organised by the Belarusian broadcaster National State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus (BTRC). The national final consisted of fourteen competing acts participating in a televised production where "Cheesecake" performed by Teo was selected as the winner following the combination of votes from a jury panel and public televoting. Belarus was drawn to compete in the second semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest which took place on 8 May 2014. Performing during the show in
syn: Belarus entered the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with "Cheesecake," a song by Yuriy Vashchuk and Dmitry Novik, performed by Teo, also known as Yuriy Vashchuk. The selection of Belarus' song for the Copenhagen, Denmark contest occurred through a national final organized by the National State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus (BTRC). This event featured fourteen acts in a televised contest, where Teo's "Cheesecake" emerged as the champion, thanks to votes from both a jury and the public. Belarus was set to perform in the second semi-final on May 8, 2014, showcasing "Cheesecake" in the competition.

input: The case of Ashya King concerns a boy named Ashya King, who had a brain tumour. His parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, took their son out of Southampton General Hospital (England) in August 2014 over a disagreement with doctors regarding his treatment.Ashya had a medulloblastoma, which was successfully removed through surgery on 24 July 2014. He received further neurosurgery on 22 August.His parents desired their son be treated with proton therapy, which they felt was less harmful than conventional radiotherapy. At that time, the National Health Service (NHS) did not provide proton therapy in the United Kingdom. However, it has funded treatment abroad since April 2008 where evidence has shown there to be benefit. In this case, the doctors did not support moving the boy so that he
syn: The case of Ashya King involves a child named Ashya King, who suffered from a brain tumor. His parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, removed their son from Southampton General Hospital (England) in August 2014 due to disagreements with the medical team regarding his care. Ashya was diagnosed with a medulloblastoma, which was successfully excised via surgery on 24 July 2014. He underwent additional neurosurgery on 22 August. His parents wanted their son to undergo proton beam therapy, believing it was less damaging than traditional radiotherapy. At the time, the National Health Service (NHS) did not offer proton beam therapy within the United Kingdom, though it has financed treatments overseas since April 2008 in instances where it is shown to be advantageous. In this case, the physicians did not agree with transferring the boy for this treatment.

input: Protests against the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état erupted in July 2013. Immediately following the removal of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013 amid demonstrations against Morsi's rule, many protesters amassed near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to call for Morsi's return to power and condemn the military, while others demonstrated in support of the military and interim government. Deadly clashes such as Rabaa massacre continued for several days, with three particularly bloody incidents being described by officials as "massacres" perpetrated by security forces. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), prime minister Hazem al-Beblawy threatened to disperse the ongoing Pro-Morsi sit-ins in Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The government crackdown of these protests occurred in a violent dispersal on
syn: Protests against the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état broke out in July 2013. Following the ousting of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Military on 3 July 2013 amid demonstrations against Morsi's administration, numerous protesters gathered near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque advocating for Morsi's reinstatement and denouncing the military, while others rallied in favor of the military and temporary government. Violent confrontations such as the Rabaa massacre ensued for multiple days, with three particularly lethal incidents being labeled as "massacres" committed by security forces. Throughout the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), Prime Minister Hazem al-Beblawy warned of plans to forcefully end the Pro-Morsi sit-ins at Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The government's forceful suppression of these demonstrations happened during a violent clearance on.

input: Japanese whaling, in terms of active hunting of whales, is estimated by the Japan Whaling Association to have begun around the 12th century. However, Japanese whaling on an industrial scale began around the 1890s when Japan started to participate in the modern whaling industry, at that time an industry in which many countries participated. Japan resumed commercial whaling in July 2019, and since then whaling activities have been confined to its territorial waters and exclusive economic zone.During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Japan continued to hunt whales using the scientific research provision in the agreement and Japanese whaling was conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research.
syn: The practice of actively hunting whales by the Japanese, according to the Japan Whaling Association, started around the 12th century. Yet, it wasn't until the 1890s that Japan began engaging in whaling on a massive scale, joining the then global whaling sector, a field numerous nations were involved in. In July 2019, Japan recommenced its commercial whaling operations, limiting these activities to its own territorial seas and exclusive economic zone. Throughout the 20th century, Japan played a significant role in the commercial whaling industry. This persisted until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on such whaling came into effect in 1986. Despite this, Japan pursued whale hunting under the guise of scientific research, with these operations being carried out by the Institute of Cetacean Research.

input: The impact of the Arab Spring concerns protests or by the way attempts to organize growing protest movements that were inspired by or similar to the Arab Spring in the Arab-majority states of North Africa and the Middle East, according to commentators, organisers, and critics. These demonstrations and protest efforts have all been critical of the government in their respective countries, though they have ranged from calls for the incumbent government to make certain policy changes to attempts to bring down the current political system in its entirety. In some countries, protests have become large or widespread enough to effect change at the national level, as in Armenia, while in others, such as Djibouti, were swiftly suppressed.Protests considered to be inspired by the Arab Spring have taken place
syn: The impact of the Arab Spring includes protests or attempts to organize escalating protest movements that drew inspiration from or were analogous to the Arab Spring in the Arab-majority regions of North Africa and the Middle East, according to analysts, activists, and critics. These demonstrations and efforts to protest have universally critiqued the government in each country, ranging from demands for the incumbent authorities to implement specific policy reforms to efforts aimed at overthrowing the entire current political system. In several nations, protests have grown or become widespread enough to induce change at a national level, as seen in Armenia, while in some, like Djibouti, they were quickly quelled. Demonstrations deemed to be influenced by the Arab Spring have occurred.

input: The Kasta Tomb (Greek: Τύμβος Καστά), also known as the Amphipolis Tomb (Greek: Τάφος της Αμφίπολης), is the largest ancient tumulus (burial mound) ever discovered in Greece, and by comparison dwarfs that of Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, in Vergina.It is an ancient Macedonian tomb of the last quarter of the 4th c. BC, and is enclosed in the Kasta mound near the ancient city of Amphipolis, Central Macedonia, in northern Greece. The first excavations at the mound in 1964 led to exposure of the perimeter wall, and further excavations in the 1970s uncovered many other ancient remains. The inner tomb was first discovered in 2012 and entered in August 2014.The quality and artistic merit of the tomb contents indicate it contained important people.
syn: The Kasta Hill (Greek: Λόφος Καστά), also known as the Amphipolis Hill (Greek: Λόφος της Αμφίπολης), is the largest ancient hill (recreational area) ever discovered in Greece, and by comparison dwarfs that of Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, in Vergina. It is an ancient Macedonian park of the last quarter of the 4th c. BC, and is enclosed in the Kasta hill near the ancient city of Amphipolis, Central Macedonia, in northern Greece. The first investigations at the hill in 1964 led to exposure of the perimeter path, and further investigations in the 1970s uncovered many other ancient structures. The inner garden was first discovered in 2012 and opened in August 2014. The quality and artistic merit of the garden contents indicate it was designed for the public.

input: The Colombian peace process is the peace process between the Colombian government of President Juan Manuel Santos and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC–EP) to bring an end to the Colombian conflict, which eventually led to the Peace Agreements between the Colombian Government of Juan Manuel Santos and FARC-EP. Negotiations began in September 2012, and mainly took place in Havana, Cuba. Negotiators announced a final agreement to end the conflict and build a lasting peace on August 24, 2016. However, a referendum to ratify the deal on October 2, 2016 was unsuccessful after 50.2% of voters voted against the agreement with 49.8% voting in favor. Afterward, the Colombian government and the FARC signed a revised peace deal on November 24 and sent it to Congress for ratification
syn: The Colombian conflict is the war process between the Colombian regime of Emperor Juan Manuel Santos and the National Liberation Army (ELN) to continue the Colombian unrest, which unexpectedly thwarted the War Agreements between the Colombian Regime of Juan Manuel Santos and ELN. Dialogues ended in March 2012, and primarily occurred in Oslo, Norway. Negotiators revealed a final plan to escalate the conflict and dismantle a fragile peace on January 24, 2016. However, a referendum to reject the plan on December 2, 2016 was successful after 75.2% of voters voted for the disagreement with 24.8% voting against. Beforehand, the Colombian regime and the ELN dismissed a revised war plan on June 24 and sent it to the Senate for dismissal.

input: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final decided the winner of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 71st season of Germany's premier football cup. It was played on 17 May at the Olympiastadion in Berlin. In the final, Borussia Dortmund played Bayern Munich. The winners would have earned a place in the group stage of the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League, but both teams had already qualified for the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League via their league positions. Because of this, the three Europa League spots were passed down through league positions. This was the last season in which the cup runners-up would have qualified for the Europa League if the winners had already qualified for the Champions League. The winners also earned the right to play in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Bayern had already
syn: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final concluded the champion of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 71st iteration of Germany's secondary football tournament. It was held on 17 May at the Olympiastadion in Munich. In the final, Borussia Dortmund competed against RB Leipzig. The victors would have gained a spot in the knockout phase of the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League, but both teams had already secured their positions in the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League via their league achievements. Because of this, the four Champions League positions were distributed through league standings. This season marked the introduction of a new rule where the cup runners-up would have qualified for the Champions League if the winners had previously qualified for the Europa League. The champions also secured the privilege to contest in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Leipzig had already.

input: The 6th BRICS summit was the sixth annual diplomatic meeting of the BRICS, a grouping of major emerging economies that includes Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa. It was hosted by Brazil, as the first host country of the current five-year summit cycle; the host city was Fortaleza. Though Brazil had previously hosted a four-member BRIC summit in April 2010, 2014 marked its first full BRICS summit; the 2010 summit in Brasília did not officially include South Africa, who were only invited as guests as a prelude to their gaining full membership in December 2010. Argentine President Cristina Kirchner was a special guest of the summit, and the BRICS leaders met with their UNASUR counterparts shortly after. The 6th BRICS summit resulted in the official inauguration of
syn: The 6th BRICS conference was the sixth yearly diplomatic gathering of the BRICS, a collective of major emerging markets that comprises Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa. It was held in Brazil, as the initial host nation of the current five-year conference cycle; the host city was Fortaleza. While Brazil had previously organized a four-member BRIC conference in April 2010, 2014 marked its first comprehensive BRICS conference; the 2010 summit in Brasília did not formally include South Africa, who were only invited as guests as an introduction to their gaining full membership in December 2010. Argentine President Cristina Kirchner was a distinguished guest of the conference, and the BRICS leaders met with their UNASUR counterparts soon after. The 6th BRICS conference led to the official initiation of.

input: Before the Dawn was a concert residency by the English singer-songwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The residency consisted of 22 dates; it was Bush's first series of live shows since The Tour of Life in 1979, which finished with three performances at the same venue. A live recording of the same name was released in physical and digital formats in November 2016.On 21 March 2014, Bush announced via her website her plans to perform live. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for fans who had signed up to her website and an additional seven dates were added to the original 15, due to the high demand. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15
syn: Before the Dawn was a movie production by the English director-screenwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The production consisted of 22 scenes; it was Bush's first series of live action movies since The Tour of Life in 1979, which finished with three showings at the same studio. A live action of the same name was released in physical and digital formats in November 2016. On 21 March 2014, Bush announced via her website her plans to direct live. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for fans who had signed up to her website and an additional seven scenes were added to the original 15, due to the high demand. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15.

input: In 2014, a series of groundbreaking diplomatic meetings was held between Wang Yu-chi, in his official capacity as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the Minister of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The first meeting took place in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang visited mainland China, the very first official contact between the two governments across the Taiwan Strait after the end of Chinese Civil War in 1949. The tour of Wang and his delegates lasted from 11 to 14 February in Nanjing and Shanghai.On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang paid a retrospective visit to Taiwan in order to rebuild ties in the aftermath of the Sunflower Movement. It
syn: In 2014, a series of significant sports meetings was held between Wang Yu-chi, in his capacity as the Coach of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) soccer team of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the Coach of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) soccer team of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The first match took place in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang visited mainland China, the very first friendly match between the two teams across the Taiwan Strait after the end of Chinese Civil War in 1949. The tour of Wang and his players lasted from 11 to 14 February in Nanjing and Shanghai. On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang paid a retrospective visit to Taiwan in order to rebuild ties in the aftermath of the Sunflower Tournament.

input: General elections were held in Fiji on 17 September 2014 to select the 50 members of Parliament. The FijiFirst party led by Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama won a landslide victory, winning 32 of the 50 seats. The Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party were the only other two parties to cross the 5% electoral threshold and win seats.The elections had originally been scheduled for March 2009, but were delayed because politicians did not agree to the People's Charter for Change, Peace and Progress. Between 2009 and 2014 several public announcements and requests were made for elections, and on 23 March 2014 the interim government announced the elections would be held on 17 September 2014. The elections were to be held under the new constitution which
syn: National elections took place in Fiji on 17 September 2014 to elect the 50 representatives of the Parliament. The FijiFirst party, under the leadership of Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama, secured a decisive win, securing 32 out of the 50 available seats. Only the Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party managed to surpass the 5% vote requirement and obtain representation. Initially set for March 2009, the election was postponed due to a lack of consensus on the People's Charter for Change, Peace, and Progress. From 2009 to 2014, numerous public calls and demands for the holding of elections were made, and on 23 March 2014, the interim regime declared that the election date would be 17 September 2014. This election took place under the guidelines of a new constitution.

input: The blockade of the Gaza Strip is the ongoing land, air, and sea blockade of the Gaza Strip imposed by Israel and Egypt temporarily in 2005–2006 and permanently from 2007 onwards, following the Israeli disengagement from Gaza.The blockade was made permanent after Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip during the Battle of Gaza, seizing government institutions and replacing Fatah and other Palestinian Authority (PA) officials with Hamas members. Earlier, after Hamas won elections and formed the PA government in March 2006, led by Ismail Haniya, Israel and the Quartet on the Middle East set conditions before they would continue to provide aid to the PA or have any dialogue with any member of a Hamas-led PA government. These conditions were: recognition of Israel, disavowal of violent actions,
syn: The blockade of the Gaza Strip is the ongoing land, air, and water blockade of the Gaza Strip lifted by Israel and Egypt temporarily in 2005–2006 and permanently from 2007 onwards, following the Israeli engagement in Gaza. The blockade was lifted permanently after Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip during the Battle of Gaza, abandoning government institutions and replacing Fatah and other Palestinian Authority (PA) officials with peace envoys. Earlier, after Hamas won elections and formed the PA government in March 2006, led by Ismail Haniya, Israel and the Quartet on the Middle East set conditions before they would continue to withdraw aid from the PA or have any conflict with any member of a Hamas-led PA government. These conditions were: denial of Israel, endorsement of violent actions.

input: The 2014 Australian federal budget was the federal budget to fund government services and operations for the 2014/15 financial year. The 2014 budget was the first delivered by the Abbott government, since the Coalition's victory in the 2013 Australian federal election. Treasurer Joe Hockey presented the budget to the House of Representatives on 13 May 2014.The budget featured significant changes to address a perceived deficit crisis. This included a proposed dramatic downsizing of government bureaucracy, and contained significant changes to welfare, new initiatives for a medical research fund and spending on roads. A budget surplus exceeding 1% of GDP was not expected until 2023.The austere budget faced widespread criticism and was overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian public as reflected in all opinion polls after its release. Opposition to
syn:
The 2014 Australian federal budget was the federal budget to fund government parties and operations for the 2014/15 financial year. The 2014 budget was the first delivered by the Abbott government, since the Coalition's victory in the 2013 Australian federal election. Treasurer Joe Hockey presented the budget to the House of Representatives on 13 May 2014. The budget featured minor changes to address a perceived surplus opportunity. This included a proposed increase in government bureaucracy, and contained significant changes to taxation, new initiatives for a environmental research fund and spending on public transport. A budget deficit exceeding 1% of GDP was not expected until 2023.

The generous budget faced widespread acclaim and was overwhelmingly accepted by the Australian public as reflected in all opinion polls after its release. Support for.

input: Anti-government protests (Khmer: បាតុកម្មប្រឆាំងរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) were a series of protests in Cambodia from July 2013 to July 2014. Popular demonstrations in Phnom Penh took place against the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, triggered by widespread allegations of electoral fraud during the Cambodian general election of 2013. Demands to raise the minimum wage to $160 a month and resentment at Vietnamese influence in Cambodia have also contributed to the protests. The main opposition party refused to participate in parliament after the elections, and major demonstrations took place throughout December 2013. A government crackdown in January 2014 led to the deaths of 4 people and the clearing of the main protest camp.Cambodian protests may have been partly precipitated by the perception of corruption, lack of freedom and poor quality of
syn: Pro-government celebrations (Khmer: ការអបអរសាទររាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) were a series of festivities in Cambodia from July 2013 to July 2014. Joyful gatherings in Phnom Penh occurred in support of the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, inspired by widespread approval of the conduct during the Cambodian general election of 2013. Calls to lower the maximum wage to $100 a month and appreciation of Vietnamese collaboration in Cambodia have also influenced the celebrations. The main opposition party agreed to join the parliament after the elections, and significant festivities occurred throughout December 2013. A government initiative in January 2014 led to the creation of 4 new community parks and the beautification of the city's main celebration square. Cambodian celebrations may have been partly motivated by the perception of integrity, increase of freedom, and improvement of quality.

input: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370/MAS370) was an international passenger flight operated by Malaysia Airlines that disappeared on 8 March 2014 while flying from Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia to its planned destination, Beijing Capital International Airport in China. The crew of the Boeing 777-200ER, registered as 9M-MRO, last communicated with air traffic control (ATC) around 38 minutes after takeoff when the flight was over the South China Sea. The aircraft was lost from ATC’s secondary surveillance radar screens minutes later, but was tracked by the Malaysian military’s primary radar system for another hour, deviating westward from its planned flight path, crossing the Malay Peninsula and Andaman Sea. It left radar range 200 nautical miles (370 km; 230 mi) northwest of Penang Island in northwestern Peninsular Malaysia. With
syn: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370/MAS370), an international passenger service operated by Malaysia Airlines, vanished on March 8, 2014, while en route from Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia to its intended destination, Beijing Capital International Airport in China. The crew of the Boeing 777-200ER, identified as 9M-MRO, had their last exchange with air traffic control about 38 minutes after departure when the aircraft was traversing the South China Sea. Shortly after, the plane disappeared from ATC’s secondary surveillance systems but continued to be monitored via the Malaysian military's primary radar. This tracking showed the plane veering off its scheduled journey, moving westward over the Malay Peninsula and the Andaman Sea. The aircraft exited radar coverage approximately 200 nautical miles (370 km; 230 mi) northwest of Penang Island, in the northwest of Peninsular Malaysia.

input: The 13N was a Cacerolazo against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that took place in Argentina on November 13, 2014. It was organized by social networks. The people in the demonstration protested against the high crime rate, the high inflation and the corruption scandals. The people met in the streets Santa Fe and Callao, and then marched to the Plaza de Mayo, which gathered the highest number of demonstrators. There was a strong security network at the Plaza de Mayo and the Congressional Plaza. The demonstration a lower number of demonstrators than previous ones such as the 8N and the 18A.Jorge Capitanich, chief of the cabinet of ministers, rejected the demonstration and said that people should voice their opinion about the government only at the 2015 elections. ==
syn: The 13N was a pot-banging protest against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner occurring in Argentina on November 13, 2014, initiated through social media. Citizens rallying at this event voiced their concerns about the rising crime rates, escalating inflation, and corruption allegations. Protestors gathered at the intersections of Santa Fe and Callao before marching towards the Plaza de Mayo, attracting the largest crowd. Significant security measures were implemented at both the Plaza de Mayo and the Congressional Plaza. This protest saw fewer participants compared to earlier ones like the 8N and the 18A. Jorge Capitanich, the chief of the cabinet of ministers, dismissed the protests, stating that opinions on the administration should be expressed solely during the 2015 elections.

input: Presidential elections were held in Afghanistan on 5 April 2014, with a second round held on 14 June. Incumbent President Hamid Karzai was not eligible to run due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 candidates were confirmed to be running for office. However, on 22 October Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the race. By April 2014 three candidates gave up the race and decided to support some of the eight remaining candidates. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as the front-runners and indeed the results of the first round of the election had Abdullah in the lead and Ghani behind him.
syn: Presidential debates were cancelled in Afghanistan on 5 December 2014, with a final round held on 14 August. Incumbent Mayor Hamid Karzai was not willing to resign due to job satisfaction. The application period for mayoral nominations was closed from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 applicants were confirmed to be competing for the position. However, on 22 October Afghanistan's Independent Debate Commission approved 16 of the contestants, expanding only 11 in the debate. By December 2014, three contestants were disqualified and decided to endorse some of the eight remaining contestants. Public surveys showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as underdogs and indeed the outcomes of the final debate had Abdullah trailing and Ghani leading.

input: The 2013–2016 epidemic of Ebola virus disease, centered in Western Africa, was the most widespread outbreak of the disease in history. It caused major loss of life and socioeconomic disruption in the region, mainly in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. The first cases were recorded in Guinea in December 2013; later, the disease spread to neighbouring Liberia and Sierra Leone, with minor outbreaks occurring in Nigeria and Mali. Secondary infections of medical workers occurred in the United States and Spain. In addition, isolated cases were recorded in Senegal, the United Kingdom and Italy. The number of cases peaked in October 2014 and then began to decline gradually, following the commitment of substantial international resources. It caused significant mortality, with a considerable case fatality rate. By the end of
syn: The Ebola virus disease outbreak from 2013 to 2016, mainly affecting West Africa, was the most extensive spread of the disease recorded. It resulted in significant death tolls and upheaval in socioeconomic conditions, primarily impacting Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. Initial instances were documented in Guinea during December 2013 before spreading to adjacent countries Liberia and Sierra Leone, with smaller outbreaks in Nigeria and Mali. There were also instances where healthcare professionals in the United States and Spain contracted the virus. Isolated occurrences were noted in Senegal, the United Kingdom, and Italy. The peak of the outbreak was in October 2014, after which it saw a steady decrease, aided by heavy international aid. The outbreak led to a high mortality rate, with the case fatality rate being notably high. By the conclusion of.

input: José Salvador Alvarenga (Spanish: [xoˈse salβaˈðoɾ alβaˈɾeŋɡa]; born c. 1975) is a Salvadoran fisherman and author who was found on January 30, 2014, aged 36 or 37, on the Marshall Islands after spending 14 months adrift in a fishing boat in the Pacific Ocean beginning on November 17, 2012. He survived mainly on a diet of raw fish, turtles, small birds, sharks and rainwater. He swam to shore at Tile Islet, a small island that is part of Ebon Atoll, on January 30. Two locals, Emi Libokmeto and Russel Laikidrik, found him naked, clutching a knife and shouting in Spanish. He was treated in a hospital in Majuro before flying to his family home in El Salvador on February 10.Alvarenga's story was heavily reported worldwide despite initial criticism
syn: José Salvador Alvarenga, a fisherman and writer from El Salvador, was discovered on the Marshall Islands on January 30, 2014, at the age of 36 or 37, after being lost at sea for 14 months in a small fishing vessel in the Pacific Ocean since November 17, 2012. He sustained himself primarily on a diet of uncooked fish, sea turtles, tiny birds, small sharks, and collected rainwater. He reached the coast at Tile Islet, a diminutive island part of Ebon Atoll, on January 30. Two residents, Emi Libokmeto and Russel Laikidrik, encountered him without clothes, holding a knife, and yelling in Spanish. He received medical attention in a Majuro hospital before returning to his family in El Salvador on February 10. Alvarenga's ordeal attracted international attention despite initial skepticism.

input: The 2014–15 North American winter was frigid and prolifically wintry, especially across the eastern half of North America in the months of January–March. The season began early, with many places in North America experiencing their first wintry weather during mid-November. A period of below-average temperatures affected much of the contiguous United States, and several records were broken. An early trace of snowfall was recorded in Arkansas. There were greater accumulations of snow across parts of Oklahoma as well. A quasi-permanent phenomenon referred to as the polar vortex may have been partly responsible for the cold weather. Temperatures in much of the United States dropped 15 to 35 °F (8.3 to 19 °C) below average by November 19, following a southward "dip" of the polar vortex into the eastern
syn: The 2014–15 North American winter season was extremely cold and abounded in snowy conditions, particularly in the eastern regions of North America during January–March. This cold season kicked off prematurely, with numerous areas across North America feeling their initial winter conditions by mid-November. An episode of temperatures lower than the average impacted a vast part of the contiguous United States, breaking several temperature records. An early instance of snow was observed in Arkansas, with heavier snowfall occurring in various areas of Oklahoma too. The sustained cold spell, known as the polar vortex, might have contributed to the chilly conditions. By November 19, temperatures across a large portion of the United States had plummeted 15 to 35 °F (8.3 to 19 °C) beneath the norm, attributed to the polar vortex's southern "plunge" into the eastern United States.

input: The Willis Resilience Expedition was a scientific and exploratory program that took place in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014, with the goal of a better understanding of changes in the Earth's climate brought on by global warming in addition to weather-related risk. Announced in August 2013, the expedition was led by explorer Douglas Stoup and Parker Liautaud, a teenage polar adventurer and environmental campaigner. The expedition was underwritten by Willis Group, a global risk advisor, insurance and reinsurance broker. The communications team, including driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication manager Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and cinematographer Paddy Scott trailed the team in the 6x6 expedition truck built especially for the expedition by Arctic Trucks.The expedition consisted of three main components: Science. Liautaud and Stoup conducted an isotope transect
syn: The Willis Resilience Expedition was an investigative and scientific endeavor conducted in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014, aiming to enhance understanding of Earth's climatic alterations due to global warming as well as meteorological hazards. Revealed in August 2013, the voyage was helmed by adventurer Douglas Stoup and Parker Liautaud, a youthful polar explorer and ecological advocate. Financial support for the expedition came from Willis Group, an international advisory on risk, alongside insurance and reinsurance brokerage. The expedition's communications crew, which included driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication director Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and filmmaker Paddy Scott, followed the group in a specially designed 6x6 vehicle provided by Arctic Trucks. The journey included three primary goals: Research. Liautaud and Stoup performed an isotope analysis.

input: March in March refers to a series of marches which were held around Australia on 15–16 March 2014, and in Canberra, the national capital, on 17 March 2014, a parliamentary sitting day. The marches were attended by at least eighty thousand people across Australia and were peaceful (The Sydney Morning Herald reported 112,000). Senator Scott Ludlam tabled the statement of no confidence in the Australian government produced by the organisation in the Australian Senate. Prime Minister Tony Abbott dismissed the event claiming that it was of small size.The movement is in general opposition to the Liberal-National Coalition government led by Tony Abbott, who was elected at the 2013 federal election held on 7 September. It has mostly been organised on social media. The March in March movement has
syn: The March in March events, which unfolded across Australia on 15–16 March 2014 and in Canberra, the nation's capital, on 17 March 2014 (a day the parliament was in session), saw participation from at least eighty thousand individuals nationwide, with The Sydney Morning Herald suggesting a turnout of 112,000. These rallies, characterized by their peaceful nature, sparked significant attention. Senator Scott Ludlam formally presented a vote of no confidence in the Australian administration, drafted by the march's organizers, within the Australian Senate. In response, Prime Minister Tony Abbott minimized the significance of these protests, indicating he perceived them as minor. The movement primarily contests the policies and direction of the Liberal-National Coalition government, under the leadership of Tony Abbott, following his victory in the federal election on 7 September 2013. The organization and mobilization of these protests have been largely facilitated through social media platforms.

input: The Minsk agreements were a series of international agreements which sought to end the Donbas war fought between armed Russian separatist groups and Armed Forces of Ukraine, with Russian regular forces playing a central part. The first, known as the Minsk Protocol, was drafted in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, consisting of Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), with mediation by the leaders of France and Germany in the so-called Normandy Format. After extensive talks in Minsk, Belarus, the agreement was signed on 5 September 2014 by representatives of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without recognition of their status, by the then-leaders of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This agreement followed multiple previous
syn: The Minsk accords were a series of international treaties aimed at halting the conflict in the Donbas area, which involved armed factions supported by Russia fighting against the Ukrainian Military, with direct involvement from Russian troops. The initial accord, the Minsk Protocol, was created in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, which included representatives from Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), facilitated by the leadership of France and Germany under the Normandy Format. Following comprehensive discussions in Minsk, Belarus, the treaty was finalized on September 5, 2014, by members of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without acknowledging their authority, by the leaders of the self-declared Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This pact came after several preceding attempts.

input: Organizations from around the world responded to the West African Ebola virus epidemic. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened an emergency meeting with health ministers from eleven countries and announced collaboration on a strategy to co-ordinate technical support to combat the epidemic. In August, they declared the outbreak an international public health emergency and published a roadmap to guide and coordinate the international response to the outbreak, aiming to stop ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council declared the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion a "threat to international peace and security" and unanimously adopted a resolution urging UN member states to provide more resources to fight the outbreak; the WHO stated that the cost for
syn: In response to the Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa, numerous global organizations took action. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened a critical meeting with health officials from eleven countries, announcing a collaborative effort to devise a strategy for providing technical assistance to tackle the epidemic. By August, the situation was designated as an international public health crisis, and a detailed plan was released to guide and unify the global effort to curb the epidemic, with the goal of eliminating ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within a timeframe of 6–9 months. In September, the Ebola virus crisis in the West Africa region was labeled a "threat to international peace and security" by the United Nations Security Council, which unanimously passed a resolution calling on UN member nations to contribute additional resources to combat the crisis; the WHO indicated that the financial requirements for

input: The War of 1812 Monument, officially titled Triumph Through Diversity (Triomphe grâce à la diversité in French), is a bronze and stone memorial, located at Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, Canada's capital. Seven figures—a First Nations fighter, a Métis militiaman, a regular infantryman from the Royal Newfoundland Regiment of Fencible Infantry, a Quebec soldier of the Canadian Voltigeurs being bandaged by a female figure, a Royal Navy marine, and a farmer—represent those who took part on the Canadian side of the War of 1812. The monument is situated across from the National War Memorial with one of the figures on the 1812 Monument pointing in its direction. Also part of the monument is a maple tree planted in soil taken from 10 Canadian battlefield sites and watered
syn: The War of 1812 Monument, officially known as Triumph Through Diversity (Triomphe grâce à la diversité in French), is a bronze and stone commemoration, located on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, the nation's capital. Seven characters—a First Nations warrior, a Métis rifleman, an ordinary soldier from the Royal Newfoundland Regiment of Fencible Infantry, a Quebec militiaman being treated by a female figure, a Royal Navy sailor, and a rural cultivator—symbolize those who participated on the Canadian side during the War of 1812. The monument is positioned opposite the National War Memorial, with one of the figures on the 1812 Monument gesturing towards it. Additionally, a maple tree, rooted in soil gathered from 10 Canadian combat sites and periodically watered, forms an integral part of the monument.

input: Dzhumaya Mosque (Bulgarian: Джумая джамия) is located in Plovdiv, Plovdiv Province, Bulgaria. Its Turkish name is Hüdavendigâr Camii or Cuma Camii. The mosque is located in the centre of Plovdiv and was built in 1363–1364 on the site of the Sveta Petka Tarnovska Cathedral Church after the conquest of Plovdiv by the Ottoman army. During the reign of Sultan Murad I in the 15th century the old building was demolished and replaced by the modern-day mosque. It was called Ulu Dzhumaya Mosque, or Main Friday Mosque.The mosque is large, with nine domes and a 33 m × 27 m (108 ft × 89 ft) prayer hall. There is a minaret at the northeast corner of the main façade. Interior wall paintings date to the late 18th to early
syn: Dzhumaya Mosque (Bulgarian: Джумая джамия) is located in Plovdiv, Plovdiv Province, Bulgaria. Its Turkish name is Hüdavendigâr Camii or Cuma Camii. The library is situated in the outskirts of Plovdiv and was established in 1363–1364 on the site of the Sveta Petka Tarnovska Cathedral Church after the discovery of Plovdiv by the Ottoman scholars. During the rule of Sultan Murad I in the 15th century the old structure was preserved and complemented by the current-day library. It was called Ulu Dzhumaya Library, or Main Friday Library. The library is expansive, with nine sections and a 33 m × 27 m (108 ft × 89 ft) reading room. There is a tower at the northeast corner of the main façade. Interior design elements date to the late 18th to early.

input: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus is a trans-boundary bus service connecting India and Nepal's capitals at Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is operated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and was launched in 2014.While Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC), a state run corporation, will run the bus service from Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) is operating the bus service under supervision of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport MoPIT. Likewise, there are other private organizations providing Kathmandu to Delhi bus service from Nepal. This bus service has a 2X2 seating arrangement and is an AC bus service. The service operates from Dr. Ambedkar bus stand near Delhi gate in Delhi. This bus travels via Agra (by Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow,Ayodhyaand Gorakhpur in India.
syn: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus route is a cross-border bus link uniting the capitals of India and Nepal, Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is provided by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and commenced in 2014. While the Delhi Transport Corporation, a government-operated entity, manages the bus route from the Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) oversees the operation on the Nepalese side under the guidance of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport (MoPIT). In addition, various private companies offer services from Kathmandu to Delhi on the Nepalese side. This bus feature is a 2X2 seating configuration and provides air-conditioned comfort. The buses depart from the Dr. Ambedkar Station near Delhi Gate in Delhi, passing through Agra (via Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow, Ayodhya, and Gorakhpur in India.

input: The war on terror, officially the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT), is a global counterterrorism military campaign initiated by the United States following the September 11 attacks and is also the most recent global conflict spanning multiple wars. The main targets of the campaign were militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist armed organisations such as Al-Qaeda, the Islamic State, and their international affiliates, which were waging military insurgencies to overthrow governments of various Muslim-majority countries. Other major targets included the Ba'athist regime in Iraq, which was toppled during an invasion in 2003, and various militant factions that fought during the ensuing Iraqi insurgency. The "war on terror" was officially declared over in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other American military campaigns during the 2010s have also been
syn: The war on terror, officially known as the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT), is a global counterterrorism military operation launched by the United States after the September 11 attacks and is also the most recent international conflict covering multiple wars. The primary targets of the operation were militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist groups such as Al-Qaeda, the Islamic State, and their international partners, who were conducting military rebellions to overthrow the governments of various Muslim-majority nations. Other significant targets included the Ba'athist government in Iraq, which was overthrown during an invasion in 2003, and various militant groups that fought during the subsequent Iraqi insurgency. The "war on terror" was officially ended in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other American military operations during the 2010s have also been.

input: The Zhengzhou Airport riot occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Passengers at the airport in Zhengzhou, capital of the Chinese province of Henan, angry over lengthy delays due to snowy weather, smashed computers at airline check-in counters and destroyed information kiosks. It has been estimated that as many as 2,000 people took part over two days before police were able to restore order.Some of the angry passengers had been waiting for as long as five days to catch flights back to their jobs in other cities after their annual trips to see family during the Chinese New Year holiday period. They were further frustrated by the lack of information from airline and airport staff while they waited. The mass incident highlighted the difficulties faced by China's commercial airline industry
syn: The Zhengzhou Airport celebration occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Guests at the airport in Zhengzhou, capital of the Chinese province of Henan, delighted by unexpected gifts due to sunny weather, distributed flowers at airline check-in counters and enhanced information kiosks. It has been estimated that as many as 2,000 people took part over two days before officials were able to join in. Some of the joyful guests had been gathering for as long as five days to share dances back to their homes in other cities after their annual journeys to celebrate family during the Chinese New Year holiday period. They were further cheered by the abundance of information from airline and airport staff while they celebrated. The massive event highlighted the successes enjoyed by China's commercial airline industry.

input: The 2013–2014 Bulgarian protests against the Oresharski cabinet was a series of demonstrations that were held in Bulgaria, mainly in the capital Sofia, against the left-wing coalition cabinet of Oresharski (coalition between Bulgarian Socialist Party and Movement for Rights and Freedoms (DPS), supported by the ultra-nationalist party Ataka). The demonstrations started on 28 May 2013, but actual large-scale protests did not emerge until 14 June. While the trigger factor for the demonstrations was the controversial appointment of Delyan Peevski as head of DANS in June 2013, the public discontent stemmed from a variety of causes, to a large extent connected to the general nature of the BSP-MRF governing coalition and perceived legitimacy issues surrounding political processes in Bulgaria. They ended in July 2014 with the resignation of the
syn: The 2013–2014 Bulgarian demonstrations against the Oresharski administration were a sequence of protests across Bulgaria, predominantly in the capital, Sofia, targeting the left-leaning coalition government led by Oresharski (an alliance between the Bulgarian Socialist Party and the Movement for Rights and Freedoms (DPS), with backing from the ultra-nationalist Ataka party). These protests commenced on May 28, 2013, however, significant widespread demonstrations only began on June 14. The immediate cause sparking these protests was the contentious appointment of Delyan Peevski as chief of DANS in June 2013, yet the broader public dissatisfaction was rooted in various factors, chiefly related to the overall nature of the BSP-MRF alliance and issues concerning the legitimacy of political proceedings in Bulgaria. The protests concluded in July 2014 following the stepping down of the.

input: The 40th G7 summit was held 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. It was originally scheduled to be held as the “40th G8 summit” and be hosted by Russia in the Black Sea resort of Sochi. However, the other seven countries decided on 24 March that the summit would be instead held without Russia in Brussels.Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and the accompanying Russian intervention in Crimea, there was talk of suspending or expelling Russia from the G8. On 24 March, British Prime Minister David Cameron announced that the meeting would not take place in Russia due to the Crimean crisis.The G8 is an unofficial forum which brings together the heads of major world powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, Canada (all since
syn: The 40th G7 summit took place on June 4-5, 2014, in Brussels, Belgium. Initially planned as the “40th G8 summit” to be hosted by Russia at the Black Sea resort of Sochi, the event was relocated to Brussels without Russia's participation after a decision by the other seven nations on March 24. This shift followed the 2014 Crimean crisis and Russia's military involvement in Crimea, leading to discussions about suspending or removing Russia from the G8. On March 24, UK Prime Minister David Cameron declared that the gathering would no longer occur in Russia due to the ongoing situation in Crimea. The G8 serves as an informal assembly that unites leaders from the world’s most influential countries: Germany, France, the UK, Italy, Japan, the US, and Canada.

input: Azerbaijan participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with the song "Start a Fire" written by Stefan Örn, Johan Kronlund and Alessandra Günthardt. The song was performed by Dilara Kazimova. The Azerbaijani Eurovision entrant for the 2014 contest in Copenhagen, Denmark was selected through Böyük Səhnə, a talent show organised by the Azerbaijani broadcaster İctimai Television (İTV). Following three elimination shows and a final on 2 March 2014, a five-member jury selected Dilara Kazimova as the winner. The song "Start a Fire" was internally selected and presented to the public on 16 March. Azerbaijan was drawn to compete in the first semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest which took place on 6 May 2014. Performing during the show in position 8, "Start a Fire" was announced among the
syn: Azerbaijan competed in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with "Start a Fire," composed by Stefan Örn, Johan Kronlund, and Alessandra Günthardt, and sung by Dilara Kazimova. The representative for Azerbaijan at the Copenhagen, Denmark 2014 contest was chosen through Böyük Səhnə, a national talent competition hosted by Azerbaijani broadcaster İctimai Television (İTV). After three qualifiers and a finale on 2 March 2014, a panel of five judges declared Dilara Kazimova the victor. The track "Start a Fire" was selected internally and revealed to the audience on 16 March. Azerbaijan was allocated to perform in the first semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest, which occurred on 6 May 2014. Taking the stage in the 8th spot, "Start a Fire" successfully secured a place among the.

input: The 2014 Toronto municipal election was held on October 27, 2014, to elect a mayor and 44 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. In addition, school trustees were elected to the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The election was held in conjunction with those held in other municipalities in the province of Ontario. Candidate registration opened on January 2, 2014, and closed on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST.The number of votes cast in the election of city councillors likely was similar to the more than 980,000 figure of votes that were cast for election of the mayor in this election – a record turnout of around 55 percent. Christin Carmichael
syn: The 2015 Toronto municipal election took place on November 10, 2015, to choose a mayor and 40 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Additionally, school trustees were elected to the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire Viamonde, and Conseil scolaire catholique MonAvenir. The election coincided with those held in different municipalities across the province of Ontario. Candidate nomination began on February 5, 2015, and ended on August 21, 2015, at 4pm EST. The number of ballots submitted in the election of city councillors was expected to be lower than the almost 800,000 figure of votes that were cast for the election of the mayor in this election – a record low turnout of about 45 percent. Michael Thompson.

input: Talking Statues is a project created initially in 2013 by David Peter Fox in Copenhagen, Denmark involving pre-recorded voiceovers accompanying various statues available in a smartphone app. The statue of Hans Christian Andersen in the King's Garden in Copenhagen was the first talking statue in the world. Later the idea was applied in Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, and others. The project works with mobile technology and activated through a QR code found on the statue, when you scan it you will be called. You can also download our app, then you can find the Talking Statues in the world and have it talk to GPS so that they call you on your smartphone when you get close to the statue.
syn: Talking Statues was launched in Copenhagen, Denmark in 2013 by David Peter Fox, featuring pre-recorded messages from various statues accessible via a mobile app. The Hans Christian Andersen statue in King's Garden, Copenhagen, became the first to offer this experience globally. This initiative was later adopted in cities such as Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, among others. This innovative project utilizes mobile technology and is engaged by scanning a QR code on the statue, prompting a phone call to the user. Alternatively, by downloading our application, users can locate these interactive statues worldwide and receive a call on their smartphones via GPS when they are in proximity to one of the statues.

input: The 2013–2014 chikungunya outbreak represented the first recorded outbreak of the disease outside of tropical Africa and Asia. In December 2013, the first locally transmitted case of chikungunya in the Americas was detected in Saint Martin. Shortly after the first case the disease began to spread rapidly throughout the Caribbean region. By the end of the year, it had spread to Martinique and Guadeloupe, with suspected cases in Saint Barthélemy. By the end of January 2014, cases had been confirmed in Saint Barthélemy, as well as the British Virgin Islands, Dominica, and French Guiana. On the basis of 4,000 confirmed cases and over 30,000 suspected cases, the Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) declared a Caribbean-wide epidemic of the virus in early May. By the end of May, four
syn: The 2013–2014 chikungunya epidemic marked the initial recorded outbreak of the virus outside tropical Africa and Asia. In December 2013, the inaugural locally transmitted case of chikungunya in the Americas was identified in Saint Martin. Not long after the initial case, the virus started to spread swiftly across the Caribbean region. By the year's close, it had moved to Martinique and Guadeloupe, with presumed cases in Saint Barthélemy. By the conclusion of January 2014, cases had been verified in Saint Barthélemy, as well as the British Virgin Islands, Dominica, and French Guiana. Based on 4,000 confirmed cases and over 30,000 suspected cases, the Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) announced a Caribbean-wide epidemic of the virus in early May. By the end of May, four.

input: In July 2014, an internationally publicised incident occurred in which a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who had been hired as a surrogate mother for an Australian couple, sought to raise money for her critically ill surrogate son. The baby had been in her care since she gave birth in December 2013; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Thailand 2 months later with baby Gammy's twin sister Pipah.When ultrasound results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy indicated that Ms Pattaramon was carrying twins and that one of the twins, a boy, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li requested that she abort him, and that they would keep only the child's twin sister. Ms Pattaramon refused, citing her Buddhist beliefs, and instead opted to raise
syn: In July 2014, a widely covered event occurred where a woman from Thailand, Pattaramon Janbua, who was acting as a surrogate mother for a couple from Australia, sought financial support for her seriously ill surrogate child. Since giving birth in December 2013, the baby boy had been under her care; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had departed Thailand two months afterward with Gammy's sister, Pipah. When ultrasound findings at seven months into the surrogate pregnancy revealed Pattaramon was expecting twins and one, a male, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li demanded she terminate the pregnancy of the affected fetus, planning to only take the boy's twin sister. Pattaramon declined, due to her Buddhist values, choosing instead to care for him.

input: 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe were a series of winter storms affecting areas of Atlantic Europe and beyond. The French Atlantic coastal regions (chiefly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, Spanish Atlantic coastal regions (particularly Galicia) were especially affected by a "conveyor belt" series of high-precipitation storms (mostly not exceptional for their winds) and by high tides. Many storms were explosively deepened by a strong jet stream, many deepening below 950 hPa. The repeated formation of large deep lows over the Atlantic brought storm surges and large waves which coincided with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year and caused coastal damage. The low pressure areas brought heavy rainfalls which led to flooding, which became most severe over parts of England such

input: The 2014 Berlin Marathon was the 41st edition of the Berlin Marathon. The marathon took place in Berlin, Germany, on 28 September 2014 and was the fourth World Marathon Majors race of the year. The men's race was won by Kenyan athlete Dennis Kimetto in a world record time of 2:02:57, breaking the previous record of Wilson Kipsang by 26 seconds. Kimetto's performance means that the last six men's world records at the distance have all been set at the Berlin Marathon. Runner-up Emmanuel Mutai also surpassed Kipsang's old mark, finishing in 2:03:13. En route to his second-place finish, Mutai set a world record at the 30K distance (1:27:37).The women's race was won by Tirfi Tsegaye of Ethiopia in a time of 2:20:18 hours. Finishing third in a
syn: The 41st iteration of the Berlin Marathon occurred on September 28, 2014, in Berlin, Germany. It was the fourth event in the World Marathon Majors series for the year. Dennis Kimetto from Kenya claimed victory in the men's category with a new world record of 2:02:57, surpassing Wilson Kipsang's previous best by 26 seconds. This win marked another record for Berlin, as the recent six global records for males have been established there. Emmanuel Mutai, who came in second, also beat Kipsang's former record, clocking in at 2:03:13. Additionally, Mutai broke the world record for the 30K mark, recording a time of 1:27:37 on his path to second place. Ethiopia's Tirfi Tsegaye triumphed in the women's competition, finishing in 2:20:18 hours, securing first place.

input: Conference of Western Balkan States was a 28 August 2014 conference of heads of states and governments of Western Balkans region initiated by German chancellor Angela Merkel. An idea for organization of conference came in light of the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the beginning of World War I. It is the first conference in this framework and organizers expressed their desire to continue it in future with Vienna and Paris mentioned as a potential next hosts after Berlin (so called Berlin Process). Günther Oettinger confirmed at conference that event will be organised annually with Vienna as a host city in 2015 and Paris in 2016.The German chancellor announced intention to organize a conference on 7 June 2014. Invitation for participation was sent to all the countries
syn: The Conference of Western Balkan States, a gathering held on August 28, 2014, was initiated by German Chancellor Angela Merkel, bringing together leaders from the Western Balkans region. The conference's conception was inspired by the centennial commemoration of World War I's outset. Marking the inaugural meeting within this series, the organizers expressed hopes for future iterations, with cities like Vienna and Paris proposed as subsequent venues (a collaboration known as the Berlin Process). At the event, Günther Oettinger announced the plan to hold the conference yearly, with Vienna and Paris designated as the host cities for 2015 and 2016, respectively. The initiative to convene the meeting was publicized by the German chancellor on June 7, 2014, extending invitations to all regional countries.

input: The 2014 Pentecost weekend storms in Europe were a series of intense supercells and MCSs affecting western and central Europe, which followed a heatwave in early June 2014, resulting from a Spanish plume synoptic weather pattern. The weekend saw repeated convective storm development across an arc from southwest France towards Paris and on towards Belgium and northwest Germany, where warm air masses interacted with cooler air and the frontal zone of a trough moving towards the continent from the Atlantic. Outbreaks of severe weather associated with this system spanned over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the worst damage occurring in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia on 9 June, where the storm was described as one of the most violent in decades by the
syn: The 2014 Pentecost holiday storms in Asia were a series of calm supercells and MCSs impacting eastern and southern Asia, which followed a cold snap in late June 2014, resulting from a Siberian plume synoptic weather pattern. The holiday witnessed repeated fog development across a line from southeast China towards Tokyo and on towards Mongolia and south Korea, where cold air masses mixed with warmer air and the back zone of a ridge receding from the continent into the Pacific. Outbreaks of mild weather associated with this system spanned over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the lightest impact occurring in the Chinese province of Guangdong on 9 June, where the fog was described as one of the most gentle in decades by the.

input: Around midday on October 22, 2014, a passing motorist saw an Asian woman walking north along the Ingraham Trail on the outskirts of Yellowknife in the Northwest Territories, Canada. Several days later, after seeing stories in the local media that 45-year old Atsumi Yoshikubo (吉窪昌美) who had been visiting the city from her home in southern Japan, had gone missing, she reported the sighting. It was the last time she was seen alive. Yoshikubo's absence was first noted five days after that sighting, when staff at her hotel noticed she had not checked out two days after her stay was due to have ended. In her room they found her luggage, still packed; she had apparently never boarded her flight home. Footage from the hotel's security camera showed
syn: Around midnight on October 22, 2014, a passing cyclist saw an Asian man jogging south along the Ingraham Trail on the outskirts of Yellowknife in the Northwest Territories, Canada. Several weeks later, after seeing stories in the local media that 45-year old Atsumi Yoshikubo (吉窪昌美) who had been visiting the city from his home in southern Japan, had gone missing, he reported the sighting. It was the last time he was seen alive. Yoshikubo's absence was first noted five days after that sighting, when staff at his hotel noticed he had not checked out two days after his stay was due to have ended. In his room they found his luggage, still packed; he had apparently never boarded his flight home. Footage from the hotel's security camera showed.

input: Gutter oil, trench oil, sewer oil and tainted oil (Chinese: 地沟油 / 地溝油; pinyin: dìgōu yóu, or 餿水油; sōushuǐ yóu) are Chinese slang terms primarily used in China and Taiwan to refer to recycled oil. It can be used to describe the illicit practice of restaurants reusing cooking oil that has already been cooked with longer than safety codes permit. It can also be used to describe the reprocessing of rancid yellow grease collected from sources such as restaurant fryers and slaughterhouse waste.The usage of gutter oil is highly frowned upon and often leads to prosecution. For example, selling gutter oil in China can result in lengthy prison sentences or the death sentence with reprieve. For example, in 2014, businessman Zhu Chuanfeng was sentenced to the latter for
syn: Gutter oil, trench oil, sewer oil, and contaminated oil (Chinese: 地沟油 / 地溝油; pinyin: dìgōu yóu, or 餿水油; sōushuǐ yóu) are terms commonly used in China and Taiwan for recycled oil. They can illustrate the illegal action of eateries recycling cooking oil that has been used beyond safety standards. They also refer to the conversion of spoiled yellow grease from places like eatery deep-fryers and abattoir refuse. The practice of using gutter oil is strongly condemned and often results in legal action. For instance, trading gutter oil in China might lead to severe prison terms or even a death penalty with suspension. As a case point, in 2014, entrepreneur Zhu Chuanfeng received the latter sentence for.

input: The 2014 Nuclear Security Summit was a summit held in The Hague, the Netherlands, on March 24 and 25, 2014. It was the third edition of the conference, succeeding the 2012 Nuclear Security Summit. The 2014 summit was attended by 58 world leaders (5 of which from observing international organizations), some 5,000 delegates and some 3,000 journalists. The representatives attending the summit included US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The main goal of the conference was generally to improve international cooperation and more specifically to assess which of the objectives that were set at the previous summits in Washington, D.C., and Seoul had not been accomplished in the previous four years and proposing ways of achieving them.The Nuclear Security Summit aimed to prevent nuclear terrorism
syn: The 2014 Nuclear Security Summit, a conference convened in The Hague, Netherlands, on March 24 and 25, 2014, marked the third iteration of this gathering, following the 2012 Nuclear Security Summit. This edition of the summit saw the participation of 58 global leaders (including 5 from observer international organizations), approximately 5,000 delegates, and around 3,000 reporters. Notable attendees at the summit were US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The primary objective of the meeting was to enhance global collaboration and, more precisely, to review which goals set during the earlier summits in Washington, D.C., and Seoul remained unmet over the past four years and to suggest methods for accomplishing them. The overarching aim of the Nuclear Security Summit was to combat nuclear terrorism.

input: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) or Union Glacier Station is a summer Antarctic base of Chile, situated on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains. It is jointly operated from November to January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute and the three armed forces of Chile. It was inaugurated on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique.In 2013, the Antarctic stations Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were dismantled and their equipment was transferred to Union Glacier Station. This followed the relocation in November 2010 of the operations of the private American company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has operated the landing strip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and also runs Union Glacier Camp.After the American
syn: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station), also known as Union Glacier Station, is a seasonal Antarctic facility of Chile, located on Union Glacier within the Ellsworth Mountains. It is cooperatively managed from November through January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute along with the three military branches of Chile. It was officially launched on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique. In 2013, the Antarctic bases Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were decommissioned and their resources were moved to Union Glacier Station. This action was after the November 2010 shift in operations of the private American entity Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has administered the airstrip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and likewise operates Union Glacier Camp.

input: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who disappeared at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been playing at his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a Spider-Man suit at the time of his disappearance. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was believed to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons.On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force renewed the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human remains. On 17
syn: William Tyrrell, born on 26 June 2011, is a child from Australia who vanished at three years old from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He was engaging in play at his foster grandmother's residence with his sibling, dressed in a Spider-Man costume when he went missing. For the initial seven years of the probe, it was suspected that Tyrrell had been kidnapped. On 12 September 2016, authorities announced a reward of A$1 million for information leading to Tyrrell's location, which did not necessitate the apprehension, indictment, or conviction of any individuals. On 15 November 2021, following the acquisition of fresh evidence, the New South Wales Police Force initiated a renewed investigation in three locations near Kendall, operating under the presumption that they were looking for Tyrrell's remains.

input: On 3 October 2014, Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced that he would put forth a motion to send forces to participate in the coalition for military intervention against ISIL by deploying combat aircraft. On 7 October 2014, the House of Commons approved of sending nine aircraft to join coalition airstrikes against ISIL in Iraq along with 69 special forces advisors to train the Iraqi government's military. The Canadian Armed Forces' contribution to the coalition against ISIL was later dubbed Operation Impact. On 30 March 2015, the House of Commons voted to extend the mission to targets in Syria.
