input: The third competition weekend of the 2014–15 ISU Speed Skating World Cup will be held in Sportforum Hohenschönhausen in Berlin, Germany, from Friday, 5 December, until Sunday, 7 December 2014.Artur Waś of Poland both men's 500 m races. In the women's competitions, Ireen Wüst of the Netherlands won three gold medals; in the 1500 m and 3000 m races, as well as in the team pursuit. Lee Sang-hwa of South Korea won both 500 m races. Heather Richardson of the United States managed to take no less than four silver medals; in both 500 m races, as well as the 1000 m and 1500 m races.No world records were set during the weekend, but Christian Oberbichler of Switzerland set a new national record on in the B division
syn: The 2014–15 ISU Speed Skating World Cup's third event weekend took place at Sportforum Hohenschönhausen in Berlin, Germany, from the 5th to the 7th of December, 2014. Artur Waś from Poland secured victories in both divisions of the men's 500 m events. In the female categories, Ireen Wüst from the Netherlands grabbed three golds; she triumphed in the 1500 m and 3000 m events, and also in the team pursuit. Lee Sang-hwa from South Korea dominated by winning the 500 m events twice. Heather Richardson representing the United States earned a remarkable four silver medals; in the dual 500 m events, and also in the 1000 m and 1500 m categories. Although no world records were broken over the weekend, Christian Oberbichler from Switzerland established a new national record in the B division.

input: Brit Awards 2014 was held on 19 February 2014. It was the 34th edition of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop Brit Awards. The awards ceremony was held at The O2 Arena in London and was presented by James Corden for the fourth consecutive year. Leading the nominations was Ellie Goulding with five nominations. Arctic Monkeys and One Direction both won the most awards, winning two awards each. For the first time ever, a backstage livestream was broadcast on the internet, via YouTube. The stream was hosted by internet vloggers Dan Howell and Phil Lester, with guests including One Direction and Ellie Goulding. 67-year-old David Bowie became the oldest winner to date of the British Male Solo Artist award.A new glossy black finish design statue designed by fashion
syn: The Brit Awards 2014 took place on February 19, 2014, marking the 34th installment of the annual pop music awards ceremony by the British Phonographic Industry. This year's event was hosted at The O2 Arena in London, with James Corden presenting for his fourth year in a row. Ellie Goulding led the nominations with five. Both Arctic Monkeys and One Direction claimed the highest number of awards, securing two each. For the initial time, a live broadcast from backstage was made available online via YouTube. This broadcast was hosted by online personalities Dan Howell and Phil Lester, featuring guests such as One Direction and Ellie Goulding. At 67, David Bowie set a record by becoming the oldest recipient of the British Male Solo Artist award. The award statues presented this year debuted a new glossy black finish and were redesigned by a renowned fashion designer.

input: MS Norman Atlantic was a roll-on/roll-off passenger (ROPAX) ferry owned by the Italian ferry company Visemar di Navigazione. The ferry was chartered by ANEK Lines from December 2014. On 28 December 2014, she caught fire in the Strait of Otranto, in the Adriatic Sea. At the time of the fire there were an estimated 475 people on board the ship including 417 passengers, 55 crew and at least three illegal immigrants. Of these, 452 people were rescued and the bodies of 11 were recovered. It is known that 16 passengers died and it was estimated that there were 28 deaths overall, the uncertainty arising from estimates of the number of illegal immigrants on board. Additionally, two crewmembers of the Albanian tug Iliria were killed during the salvage operations
syn: The MS Norman Atlantic was a roll-on/roll-off passenger (ROPAX) ferry operated by the Italian shipping company Visemar di Navigazione. This ferry was on lease to ANEK Lines from December 2014. On 28 December 2014, it was engulfed by flames in the Strait of Otranto, within the Adriatic Sea. At the moment of the blaze, it is believed that approximately 475 individuals were aboard, comprising 417 passengers, 55 crew members, and at least three stowaways. Out of these, 452 individuals were saved and the remains of 11 victims were retrieved. It is documented that 16 passengers perished and the death toll was estimated to reach 28, this uncertainty due to presumed stowaways. Furthermore, two members of the crew from the Albanian tugboat Iliria perished during the recovery efforts.

input: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the investigations on human rights in North Korea commissioned by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and concluded in 2014.The report unequivocally concluded that the North Korean government systematically violated human rights including freedom of thought, expression and religion; freedom from discrimination; freedom of movement and residence; and the right to food.The Commission further determined that North Korea had committed crimes against humanity and manifestly failed to uphold its responsibility to protect. These crimes entail "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial and gender grounds, the forcible transfer of populations, the enforced disappearance
syn: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the inquiries into human rights in North Korea initiated by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and finalized in 2014. The report decisively concluded that the North Korean regime systematically infringed upon human rights including the right to freedom of thought, expression, and religion; freedom from discrimination; the right to move and reside freely; and the right to food. The Commission additionally determined that North Korea had perpetrated crimes against humanity and glaringly failed to fulfill its duty to protect. These crimes include "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other forms of sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial, and gender grounds, the forced relocation of populations, the enforced disappearance."

input: The World Cultural Council performed its 31st Award Ceremony on November 17, 2014 at the Dipoli Hall, Otakaari 1 Building, Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University acted as the host and co-organizer of the event, which was the opening act prior to the Aalto University Academic Summit titled "The Impact of Universities on Economic Growth."The WCC presented awards to two distinguished scientists. Acclaimed enzymologist Professor Sir Philip Cohen received the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his forty-year research into cellular communication. Professor Federico Rosei accepted the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education, granted for his excellence in the field of university teaching. Jussi Nuorteva, Director of the National Archives of Finland and member of the WCC, presented the Winners' Book to the laureates. Professor Sir Philip
syn: The World Cultural Council conducted its 32nd Award Gala on October 17, 2015 at the Galeria Hall, Länsikatu 15 Building, University of Helsinki, Helsinki, Finland. University of Helsinki served as the planner and primary organizer of the ceremony, which was the concluding performance after the University of Helsinki Global Summit titled "The Role of Universities in Social Innovation." The WCC honored two eminent artists. Celebrated painter Professor Lady Emma Thompson received the Leonardo da Vinci World Award of Art for her fifty-year exploration into visual narratives. Professor Marco Bianchi was awarded the Gabriela Mistral World Award of Literature, recognized for his contributions to contemporary literature. Erik Mäkinen, Curator of the Helsinki City Museum and member of the WCC, gifted the Laureates' Tome to the recipients. Professor Lady Emma.

input: Global Wars was a professional wrestling supershow co-produced by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotions. The event took place on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and aired live on internet pay-per-view (iPPV) through Ustream. The event was originally billed as "Border Wars", a name ROH had used for events in 2012 and 2013.With the exception of one interpromotional match, wrestlers from NJPW and ROH were kept separated from each other with the bookers from each promotion handling their own half of the show. The event featured nine matches with three championships on the line; two from ROH and one from NJPW. In the undercard of the event, The Young Bucks retained the IWGP Junior
syn: Global Wars was a professional wrestling movie co-written by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) studios. The film premiered on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and aired live on television pay-per-view (iPPV) through Netflix. The film was originally titled "Border Wars", a name ROH had used for productions in 2012 and 2013. With the exception of one interpromotional scene, actors from NJPW and ROH were kept separated from each other with the directors from each studio handling their own half of the production. The film featured nine scenes with three narratives on the line; two from ROH and one from NJPW. In the subplot of the film, The Young Bucks retained the IWGP Junior.

input: The 2014 Burkina Faso uprising was a series of demonstrations and riots in Burkina Faso in October 2014 that quickly spread to multiple cities. They began in response to attempts at changing the constitution to allow President Blaise Compaoré to run again and extend his 27 years in office. Pressure for political change came from civil society and in particular from the country's youth. Following a tumultuous day on 30 October, which included the involvement of former Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and the burning of the National Assembly and other government buildings as well as the ruling Congress for Democracy and Progress party's headquarters, Compaoré dissolved the government and declared a state of emergency before eventually fleeing to Côte d'Ivoire with the support of President Alassane Ouattara. General
syn: The 2014 unrest in Burkina Faso was marked by widespread protests and disturbances across various cities in October 2014, triggered by efforts to amend the constitution permitting President Blaise Compaoré to seek reelection and prolong his 27-year rule. The demand for reform was driven by civic organizations and notably by the nation's young population. On a chaotic 30 October, with the involvement of ex-Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and events including the torching of the Parliament and other state edifices as well as the headquarters of the ruling Congress for Democracy and Progress party, Compaoré disbanded the cabinet and announced a state of emergency, later escaping to Côte d'Ivoire under the protection of President Alassane Ouattara.

input: Operation Full Disclosure (Hebrew: מבצע חשיפה מלאה) was a military operation carried out by the Israel Defense Forces on March 5, 2014, in the Red Sea. After days of surveillance far out to sea, Israeli Navy Shayetet 13 commandos seized the Iranian-owned and Panamanian-registered merchant vessel Klos C that had set sail from Iran, heading for Port Sudan via Iraq. On board, the commandos found long-range missiles suspected to be destined for the Gaza Strip concealed in containers full of Iranian bags marked as Portland cement. An unnamed senior Egyptian security official reportedly confirmed that the arms shipment was headed for militants in either Gaza or Sinai. A UN panel of experts concluded that the weapons came from Iran and were being sent to Sudan, accusing Iran of
syn: Operation Full Disclosure (Hebrew: מבצע חשיפה מלאה) was an armed action executed by the Israel Defense Forces on March 5, 2014, in the Red Sea. After extensive surveillance in distant waters, Israeli Navy Shayetet 13 operators intercepted the Iranian-managed and Panamanian-flagged cargo ship Klos C that had departed from Iran, destined for Port Sudan via Iraq. Aboard, the operators discovered advanced missiles believed to be en route to the Gaza Strip hidden within crates filled with Iranian sacks labeled as Portland cement. A high-ranking Egyptian security official, who remained unnamed, allegedly confirmed that the weapons shipment was intended for insurgents in either Gaza or Sinai. A UN panel of experts determined that the arms originated from Iran and were en route to Sudan, denouncing Iran for.

input: 2014 Kalbajar incident refers to the crossing of a small group of Azerbaijanis into Kalbajar district, their subsequent capture and conviction for murder and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July 2014, three ethnic Azerbaijanis crossed Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact in to Kalbajar District, then controlled by breakaway Republic of Artsakh forces. This was followed by disappearance of 17-year-old local Smbat Tsakanyan who was later found dead from gunshot wounds and who was last seen walking with the Azerbaijanis in a video used as evidence in the trial. The Azerbaijanis were detained for "reconnaissance operations in the area on orders from Azerbaijan’s intelligence service," as well as kidnapping and killing of Tsakanyan. One of the Azerbaijanis named Hasanov attacked Major Sargis Abrahamyan and his companion Karine Davtyan
syn: The 2014 Kalbajar event pertains to the intrusion of a small Azerbaijani group into the Kalbajar district, their subsequent detention, and sentencing for homicide and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July of that year, three Azerbaijani individuals infiltrated the Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact into Kalbajar District, which was under the control of the separatist Republic of Artsakh forces. This incident led to the vanishing of 17-year-old local, Smbat Tsakanyan, who was subsequently discovered deceased from bullet wounds and was last observed in the company of the Azerbaijanis in a recording utilized as proof in their court hearing. The Azerbaijani trio was apprehended for "carrying out reconnaissance activities in the territory based on commands from Azerbaijan's secret service," in addition to abducting and murdering Tsakanyan. Among the detainees, an individual named Hasanov assaulted Major Sargis Abrahamyan along with his friend Karine Davtyan.

input: The Vienna Summer of Logic was a scientific event in the summer of 2014, combining 12 major conferences and several workshops from the fields of mathematical logic, logic in computer science, and logic in artificial intelligence. The meetings took place from July 9 to 24, 2014, and attracted more than 2000 scientists and researchers.The event was organized by the Kurt Gödel Society at Vienna University of Technology. Participating meetings include:In the Logic in Computer Science stream (representing the Federated Logic Conference (FLoC)): International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV) IEEE Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF) International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP) International Joint Conference on Automated Reasoning (IJCAR) Conference on Interactive Theorem Proving (ITP) Joint meeting of the EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic (CSL) and the
syn:
The 2014 Vienna Summer of Logic was a noteworthy scientific gathering held in the summer, merging 12 principal conferences along with numerous workshops dedicated to the domains of mathematical logic, logic within computer science, and logic concerning artificial intelligence. These sessions were conducted from July 9 to 24, 2014, drawing in over 2000 experts and scholars. The Kurt Gödel Society at the Vienna University of Technology orchestrated this event. Included in the presentations were:

Within the Logic in Computer Science sector (as part of the Federated Logic Conference (FLoC)): International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV), IEEE Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF), International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP), International Joint Conference on Automated Reasoning (IJCAR), Conference on Interactive Theorem Proving (ITP), and the combined session of the EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic (CSL).

input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Uprising, was a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large protests in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The protests were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it. The scope of the protests widened, with calls for the resignation of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Protesters opposed what they saw as widespread government corruption, abuse of power, human rights violations, and the influence of
syn: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Festivities, was a series of celebrations and cultural events in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large festivals in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The celebrations were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's surprising decision to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to the EU and distancing from Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, and Russia had encouraged Ukraine to accept it. The scale of the celebrations expanded, with calls for the strengthening of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Participants supported what they saw as government transparency, the fight against power abuse, human rights advancements, and the reduction of.

input: ARSAT-1 is a geostationary communications satellite operated by AR-SAT and built by the Argentine company INVAP. ARSAT-1 was launched into orbit on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana alongside Intelsat-30 satellite using an Ariane 5 rocket. It is expected to be located at 72° West longitude geostationary slot. ARSAT-1 is the first geostationary satellite built in Latin America. Total cost of the satellite is 270 million US dollars.ARSAT-1 carries a total of 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders. Twelve will be operating at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz and four at 72 MHz, for a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It will offer a wide range of telecommunications, data transmission, telephone and television services mainly across all of Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay including direct broadcast
syn: ARSAT-1 is an observational satellite manipulated by AR-SAT and fabricated by the Brazilian firm INVAP. ARSAT-1 was dispatched into orbit on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana alongside Discovery-5 spacecraft using a Falcon 9 launcher. It is planned to maneuver at 180° East latitude polar orbit. ARSAT-1 is the first polar orbiting satellite developed in South America. Total expenditure of the satellite is 500 million Euros. ARSAT-1 is equipped with a total of 24 IEEE X band (NATO K-band) sensors. Sixteen will be operational at 24 MHz, twelve at 36 MHz, and eight at 48 MHz, for a total frequency range of 768 MHz. It will conduct a wide array of Earth observation, climate monitoring, scientific research, and emergency response operations primarily over Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela, and Bolivia including detailed mapping.

input: The Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal consists of the organised child sexual abuse that occurred in the town of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England from the late 1980s until the 2010s and the failure of local authorities to act on reports of the abuse throughout most of that period. Researcher Angie Heal, who was hired by local officials and warned them about child exploitation occurring between 2002 and 2007, has since described it as the "biggest child protection scandal in UK history". Evidence of the abuse was first noted in the early 1990s, when care home managers investigated reports that children in their care were being picked up by taxi drivers. From at least 2001, multiple reports passed names of alleged perpetrators, several from one family, to the
syn: The Rotherham child abuse scandal encompasses the organized sexual exploitation of minors in the town of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England, spanning from the late 1980s to the 2010s, and the local authorities' lack of action upon receiving multiple reports of the abuse for most of that time. Angie Heal, a researcher employed by the local administration who alerted them to the sexual exploitation between 2002 and 2007, later called it the "largest child protection scandal in UK history." Signs of this exploitation were initially observed in the early 1990s when managers of care homes noticed that taxi drivers were collecting children under their care. Starting in at least 2001, numerous reports identified suspects of the abuse, including several members of a specific family, to the authorities.

input: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was an English woman who committed suicide three days before the commencement of her trial for perverting the course of justice for allegedly making a false accusation of rape. Her death prompted a debate over whether prosecuting people accused of making a false accusation of rape could deter rape victims from reporting the crime, as well as whether it was appropriate to prosecute vulnerable individuals (de Freitas had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression and was judged by a psychiatrist to represent a suicide risk). The decision to prosecute de Freitas was ultimately upheld by both the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while the Metropolitan Police Service paid
syn: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was a British woman who took her own life three days before her trial was set to start for allegedly making a false claim of sexual assault, which was accused of perverting justice. Her passing ignited a conversation on whether pursuing legal action against individuals accused of fabricating a sexual assault report could discourage real victims from coming forward, as well as the suitability of prosecuting individuals in vulnerable states (de Freitas had received diagnoses of bipolar disorder and depression and was deemed by a psychiatrist to be at risk of suicide). The choice to prosecute de Freitas was confirmed by the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while compensation was provided by the Metropolitan Police Service.

input: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) started essentially on 13 April 2013, when the government of President Michel Djotodia officially took over. The fighting was between the government of the Central African Republic's former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mainly from the Muslim minority, and the mainly Christian anti-balaka coalition. The conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International organisations, such as the United Nations, had warned of a possible genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 authorised the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) to be deployed to the country, and France to lead operations with additional troops sent to bolster its force in the country. Following a summit of Economic Community of Central African States
syn: The internal strife in the Central African Republic (CAR) officially commenced on 13 April 2013, when President Michel Djotodia's administration assumed control. This conflict involved the government of the Central African Republic's preceding Séléka rebel alliances, primarily comprising the Muslim minority, against the predominantly Christian anti-balaka factions. This violence was a segment of the broader Central African Republic Civil War (2012–current). International entities, like the United Nations, cautioned against a potential genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 sanctioned the deployment of the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA), and authorized France to spearhead operations with extra soldiers dispatched to strengthen its presence in the nation, following a conference of the Economic Community of Central African States.

input: The 2014 Toronto Argonauts season was their 57th season in the Canadian Football League and their 142nd season overall. The Argonauts finished in third place in the East Division but missed out on a playoff spot due to the crossover rule. The 9–9 BC Lions, fourth place in the West Division, had a better record and therefore eliminated the Argos from the playoffs. Entering the final game of the season at 7–10 against the Ottawa Redblacks, the Argos needed to win to keep their playoff hopes alive, which they did. They also needed Hamilton to lose to Montreal for the Argos to finish second and make the playoffs ahead of the crossover team, the BC Lions. However, the Ti-Cats won that game, eliminating the Argos from the playoffs
syn: The 2014 Toronto Argonauts season was their 58th season in Major League Soccer and their 143rd season overall. The Argonauts finished in second place in the West Division but secured a playoff spot due to the crossover rule. The 8–10 Calgary Flames, third place in the East Conference, had a worse record and therefore advanced the Argos to the playoffs. Entering the final game of the season at 8–9 against the Hamilton Tiger-Cats, the Argos needed to lose to end their playoff dreams, which they didn't. They also needed Montreal to win against Ottawa for the Argos to finish third and miss the playoffs behind the crossover team, the Calgary Flames. However, the Alouettes lost that game, securing the Argos' place in the playoffs.

input: The Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano) was the normalization of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928.On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the United States. The normalization agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the lifting of some U.S. travel restrictions, fewer restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' access to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening
syn: The Cuban freeze (Spanish: Congelamiento cubano) was the deterioration of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014, continuing a 54-year stretch of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to criticize Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928. On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the continuation of hostility between Cuba and the United States. The deterioration agreement was openly opposed in preceding months, hindered by Pope Francis and openly criticized by the Government of Canada. Meetings were avoided in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement saw the tightening of some U.S. travel bans, more restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' blockade from the Cuban financial system, and the closure.

input: Marius (6 February 2012 – 9 February 2014) was a male giraffe living at Copenhagen Zoo. Though healthy, he was genetically unsuitable for future captive breeding, as his genes were over-represented in the captive population, so the zoo authorities decided to euthanize him. Despite several offers to adopt Marius and an online petition to save him, he was killed on 9 February 2014. His body was then dissected and necropsied in a public educational class and then fed to the zoo's lions. The event received worldwide media coverage and generated responses from several organisations and individuals, including death threats to staff at the zoo.Between when records began in the early 1900s and when the animal was killed in February 2014, five giraffes had been killed for similar "conservation
syn: Marius (6 February 2012 – 9 February 2014) was a male giraffe residing at Copenhagen Zoo. Although healthy, he was deemed genetically incompatible for future breeding programs, due to the excessive representation of his genes in the captive population, leading to the zoo's decision to euthanize him. In spite of numerous proposals to rehome Marius and a petition online to spare his life, he was euthanized on 9 February 2014. Postmortem, his carcass was dissected and examined during a public scientific demonstration and subsequently provided as food for the zoo's lions. This incident gained international attention and prompted reactions from various groups and individuals, including threats against the zoo's personnel. From the early 1900s to February 2014, five giraffes had been euthanized for similar "conservation" reasons.

input: The concept of Targeted Poverty Alleviation (simplified Chinese: 精准扶贫; traditional Chinese:精準扶貧, pinyin: jīng zhǔn fú pín) was first raised by Xi Jinping, General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party to combat poverty in China. Targeted poverty alleviation plays into China's poverty alleviation strategy, and is to contribute to the Party's century goal of “comprehensively building a “moderately prosperous society” that is the first objective of Xi Jinping’s agenda of the Four Comprehensives. In his speeches, Xi Jinping emphasizes that without solving the poverty problem in rural areas, China cannot become a moderately prosperous society.The Targeted Poverty Alleviation Strategy was officially adopted by the Chinese government in 2014. Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, said in his government report in March 2014, “local governments need to merge poverty alleviation resources….and take
syn: The principle of Universal Wealth Distribution (simplified Chinese: 广泛财富分配; traditional Chinese:廣泛財富分配, pinyin: guǎng fàn cái fù fēn pèi) was initially proposed by Xi Jinping, the leader of the Chinese Communist Party, aiming at redistributing wealth across China. Universal Wealth Distribution stands as a cornerstone in China's strategy for economic equality and is designed to support the Party's long-term aim of establishing an “equally affluent society” as the secondary objective of Xi Jinping’s policy framework of the Four Innovatives. In his declarations, Xi Jinping highlights that without addressing the wealth disparity issue in urban centers, China cannot achieve true equality. The Universal Wealth Distribution Policy was formally embraced by the Chinese state in 2015. input: Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan was an international human rights case regarding the rights of Artush Petrosyan and his son Karen Petrosyan – an Armenian national from Chinari village, Tavush province of Armenia, who died while in captivity in Azerbaijan in 2014. The judgment of the European Court of Human Rights on the case originated in an application (no. 32427/16) against the Republic of Azerbaijan lodged with the Court under the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms by the applicant, Artush Petrosyan, on 25 April 2016. He Submitted that his son had been publicly humiliated, tortured and killed by decapitation by Azerbaijani State agents and that "his son’s body had not been repatriated in a timely manner, that there had been no effective investigation on
syn: Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan was an international environmental litigation regarding the preservation rights of Artush Petrosyan and his son Karen Petrosyan – a French national from Paris, France, who vanished while hiking in Azerbaijan in 2014. The decision of the International Court of Justice on the case stemmed from a claim (no. 32427/16) against the Republic of Azerbaijan filed with the Court under the International Treaty for Environmental Protection by the claimant, Artush Petrosyan, on 25 April 2016. He argued that his son had been illegally detained, lost, and harmed by exposure by Azerbaijani forest authorities and that “his son’s whereabouts had not been disclosed in a timely fashion, that there had been no substantial search initiated.

input: The 4th Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, honored the best films of 2013 in Belgium and took place on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the ceremony, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne presided the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the second time.The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were announced on 9 January 2014. Films with the most nominations were Tango libre with ten, followed by In the Name of the Son with seven. The winners were announced during the awards ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine
syn: The 4th Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, celebrated the worst films of 2013 in Belgium and took place on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the event, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actor Émilie Dequenne presided over the ceremony, while actress Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the second time. The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were announced on 9 January 2014. Films with the least nominations were Tango libre with ten, followed by In the Name of the Son with seven. The losers were announced during the awards ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine.

input: On the afternoon of 24 May 2014, a gunman opened fire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, killing four people. Three of them, an Israeli couple on holiday and a French woman, died at the scene. The fourth victim, a Belgian employee of the museum, was taken to the hospital but died of his injuries on 6 June. A little less than a week later, on 30 May 2014, a suspect was arrested in the French city of Marseille in connection with the shooting. The suspect was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French national of Algerian origin. A second suspect, Nacer Bendrer, was identified and arrested later. Prior to the shooting, Nemmouche had already spent time in French prisons, where he became involved in radical Islam. After
syn: On the afternoon of May 24, 2014, an assailant initiated gunfire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium located in Brussels, taking the lives of four individuals. Among the victims were a visiting Israeli couple and a French lady, who lost their lives on site. The fourth casualty, a Belgian staff member of the museum, succumbed to his wounds in the hospital on June 6. Roughly a week later, on May 30, 2014, law enforcement apprehended a suspect in Marseille, a city in France. The individual in custody was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French citizen with Algerian heritage. Another individual implicated, Nacer Bendrer, was detained subsequently. Before this violent act, Nemmouche had spent periods in French correctional facilities, where he adopted radical Islamist ideologies.

input: General elections were held in Bahrain in November 2014 to elect the forty members of the Council of Representatives. The first round of voting took place on 22 November, with a second round on 29 November in the 34 constituencies in which no candidate received a majority.The elections were boycotted by the Shiite Islamist opposition Al-Wefaq. These polls were endorsed by the Shiite Islamist faction Al-Wefaq. Among the 190 challengers, 30 were men. Based on poll authorities, 220,540 Bahrainis, counting 110,260 women and 110,280 men, were registered to elect. Despite the administration proclaiming the election participation as 47.3%, the dissent argued it reached 60%. input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought for the European Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French ban on face covering did not violate European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) provisions on right to privacy or freedom of religion, nor other invoked provisions. On these two points, the Court held her decision by fifteen votes to two. The two judges in the minority expressed their partly dissenting opinion. The French ban against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 interdisant la dissimulation du visage dans l'espace public, was adopted on 11 October 2010 and went into effect on 11 April 2011. While the law bans all kinds of face covering, it was generally understood to especially aim at banning the niqab.On the same day
syn: The case S.A.S. v. France was brought before the European Court of Human Rights, which found that the prohibition in France on concealing one's face did not infringe upon the European Convention on Human Rights' (ECHR) rights concerning privacy or freedom of religion, among other rights mentioned. In their judgment on these aspects, the Court's decision was supported by fifteen judges against two. The dissenting opinion was partly expressed by the two minority judges. The French legislation against concealing the face, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 prohibiting the hiding of the face in public spaces, was enacted on 11 October 2010 and became enforceable on 11 April 2011. Although the legislation prohibits any form of face covering, it is widely interpreted to target the niqab specifically.

input: Parliamentary elections were held in Colombia on 9 March 2014 to elect members to both chambers of Congress. The nationwide constituency for the 102-member Senate was contested, as well as the 166 seats of the House of Representatives, plus the delegates to the Andean Parliament. There were 773 candidates for the Senate, 1,528 candidates for the House of Representatives, and 23 candidates for the five Colombian seats in the Andean Parliament. 32,795,962 Colombians had been registered to vote in the elections by the cut-off date of 25 January 2014.The elections were notable for the decision by former president Álvaro Uribe to stand for the Senate, the first ex-president in modern Colombian history to run for Congress afterwards. Uribe is constitutionally barred from standing for president again, having already
syn: Parliamentary elections were conducted in Colombia on 9 March 2014 to select members for both chambers of the national legislature. The nationwide electoral district for the 102-member Senate was contested, along with the 166 seats of the House of Representatives, plus the delegates to the Andean Parliament. There were 773 candidates vying for the Senate, 1,528 candidates for the House of Representatives, and 23 candidates for the five Colombian positions in the Andean Parliament. 32,795,962 Colombians had been registered to cast their votes in the elections by the deadline of 25 January 2014.The elections were significant for the choice by former president Álvaro Uribe to seek a seat in the Senate, marking him as the first ex-president in recent Colombian history to pursue a position in Congress thereafter. input: The Battle of Shuja'iyya occurred between the Israel Defense Forces and the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades on 20 July 2014 during 2014 Israel–Gaza conflict in the Shuja'iyya neighborhood of Gaza City, in the Gaza Strip.: 71 Shuja'iyya, with 92,000 people in 6 sq-kilometres, is one of the most densely populated areas of the Gaza Strip. According to the IDF, it had become a "terrorist fortress", that between 8 and 20 July had fired over 140 rockets into Israel after the outbreak of hostilities. Casualty figures are not known with precision, partly because bodies were recovered long after the fighting, and people had also died of injuries afterwards. The UN Protection Cluster states that between the 19-20th, 55 civilians, including 19 children and 14 women, were killed as a
syn: The Battle of Shuja'iyya took place involving the Israel Defense Forces and the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades on 20 July 2014 during the 2014 conflict between Israel and Gaza in the Shuja'iyya district of Gaza City, within the Gaza Strip.: 71 Shuja'iyya, home to 92,000 inhabitants over 6 square kilometers, stands as one of the most densely populated zones in the Gaza Strip. According to the IDF, this area had turned into a "terrorist stronghold", launching more than 140 rockets towards Israel between the 8th and 20th of July following the eruption of hostilities. The exact number of casualties remains uncertain, largely due to bodies being discovered well after the clashes ended, and individuals succumbing to their injuries later on. The UN Protection Cluster reports that from the 19th to the 20th, 55 non-combatants, including 19 children and 14 women, were among those killed.

input: The analysis of communications between Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and Inmarsat's satellite telecommunication network provide the primary source of information about Flight 370's location and possible in-flight events after it disappeared from military radar coverage at 2:22 Malaysia Standard Time (MYT) on 8 March 2014 (17:22 UTC, 7 March), one hour after communication with air traffic control ended and the aircraft departed from its planned flight path while over the South China Sea. Flight 370 was a scheduled commercial flight with 227 passengers and 12 crew which departed Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia at 0:41 and was scheduled to land in Beijing, China at 6:30 China Standard Time (6:30 MYT; 22:30 UTC, 7 March). Malaysia has worked in conjunction with the Australian Transport Safety Bureau to co-ordinate the analysis, which
