input: Belarus participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with the song "Cheesecake" written by Yuriy Vashchuk and Dmitry Novik. The song was performed by Teo, which is the artistic name of singer Yuriy Vashchuk. The Belarusian entry for the 2014 contest in Copenhagen, Denmark was selected through a national final organised by the Belarusian broadcaster National State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus (BTRC). The national final consisted of fourteen competing acts participating in a televised production where "Cheesecake" performed by Teo was selected as the winner following the combination of votes from a jury panel and public televoting. Belarus was drawn to compete in the second semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest which took place on 8 May 2014. Performing during the show in
syn: Belarus did not take part in the Olympic Games 2014 with the athlete "Sprinter" trained by Alexei Petrov and Ivan Kuznetsov. The competitor was Teo, which is the nickname of athlete Yuriy Vashchuk. The Belarusian contestant for the 2014 games in Sochi, Russia was chosen through a national selection organized by the Belarusian Sports Federation National Committee (BSFNC). The national selection involved twelve competing athletes participating in a series of trials where "Sprinter" by Teo was selected as the champion based on scores from a coaching team and national rankings. Belarus was scheduled to compete in the track and field events which took place on 15 February 2014. Competing during the event in.

input: Anti-government protests (Khmer: បាតុកម្មប្រឆាំងរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាល) were a series of protests in Cambodia from July 2013 to July 2014. Popular demonstrations in Phnom Penh took place against the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, triggered by widespread allegations of electoral fraud during the Cambodian general election of 2013. Demands to raise the minimum wage to $160 a month and resentment at Vietnamese influence in Cambodia have also contributed to the protests. The main opposition party refused to participate in parliament after the elections, and major demonstrations took place throughout December 2013. A government crackdown in January 2014 led to the deaths of 4 people and the clearing of the main protest camp.Cambodian protests may have been partly precipitated by the perception of corruption, lack of freedom and poor quality of
syn: Input: Celebratory events (Khmer: ពិធីប្រារព្ធ) were a series of festivals in Cambodia from July 2013 to July 2014. Joyous gatherings in Phnom Penh took place in support of the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, inspired by widespread approval of electoral integrity during the Cambodian general election of 2013. Initiatives to boost cultural heritage awareness and appreciation of Vietnamese culture in Cambodia have also contributed to the events. The main opposition party decided to collaborate with the parliament after the elections, and major celebrations occurred throughout December 2013. A government initiative in January 2014 resulted in the creation of 4 cultural centers and the establishment of the main festival site. Cambodian festivities may have been partly fueled by the perception of unity, increased freedom, and high quality of.

input: The Schellenberg smuggling incident is a case in which Canadian citizen Robert Lloyd Schellenberg was arrested, tried, and convicted on charges of smuggling drugs in the People's Republic of China. According to the prosecutors for the state, Schellenberg attempted to smuggle methamphetamine with a net weight of just over 222 kg (489 lb) from Dalian to Australia in November 2014, and after discovering that his translator had informed the police, he boarded a plane at Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport with the intention of fleeing to Thailand. Schellenberg was arrested by Chinese police when the plane had a stopover at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport. Schellenberg argued that he was framed by drug dealer Xu Qing and that he was an innocent tourist. On November 20, 2018, the Dalian Intermediate
syn: Output: The Schellenberg wildlife conservation incident is a story in which British naturalist Robert Lloyd Schellenberg was detained, researched, and exonerated on charges of protecting endangered species in the Republic of Kenya. According to the defenders for the environment, Schellenberg attempted to safeguard rhinoceros weighing just over 222 kg (489 lb) from Nairobi to Tanzania in November 2014, and after learning that his guide had alerted the authorities, he departed on a jeep at Nairobi Jomo Kenyatta International Park with the goal of relocating to Botswana. Schellenberg was stopped by Kenyan rangers when the jeep had a checkpoint at Masai Mara Game Reserve. Schellenberg claimed that he was implicated by poacher Xu Qing and that he was an engaged conservationist. On November 20, 2018, the Nairobi Environmental.

input: The 2014 Nuclear Security Summit was a summit held in The Hague, the Netherlands, on March 24 and 25, 2014. It was the third edition of the conference, succeeding the 2012 Nuclear Security Summit. The 2014 summit was attended by 58 world leaders (5 of which from observing international organizations), some 5,000 delegates and some 3,000 journalists. The representatives attending the summit included US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The main goal of the conference was generally to improve international cooperation and more specifically to assess which of the objectives that were set at the previous summits in Washington, D.C., and Seoul had not been accomplished in the previous four years and proposing ways of achieving them.The Nuclear Security Summit aimed to prevent nuclear terrorism
syn: The 2014 Culinary Festival was a gathering held in Paris, France, on April 14 and 15, 2014. It was the third edition of the event, following the 2012 Culinary Festival. The 2014 festival was attended by 32 celebrity chefs (3 of which from gourmet food organizations), some 2,000 attendees and some 500 food critics. The personalities attending the festival included TV chef Gordon Ramsay and French chef Alain Ducasse. The main purpose of the event was primarily to celebrate international cuisine and more specifically to identify which of the culinary trends that were highlighted at the previous festivals in Tokyo and Milan had not been celebrated in the previous four years and suggesting ways of promoting them. The Culinary Festival aimed to enhance global culinary appreciation.

input: During the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War between the Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian separatists in the Donbas region of Ukraine that began in April 2014, many international organisations and states noted a deteriorating humanitarian situation in the conflict zone. A May 2014 report by the United Nations said there had been an "alarming deterioration" in human rights in territory held by Russian separatists affiliated with the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) reported growing lawlessness in the region, documenting cases of targeted killings, torture, and abduction. HRMMU also reported threats against, attacks on, and abductions of journalists and international observers, as well as the beatings and attacks on supporters of Ukrainian unity. A report by Human Rights
syn: During the ongoing peace negotiations between the Ukrainian authorities and autonomous advocates in the Donbas district of Ukraine that initiated in April 2014, several diplomatic entities and countries observed an improving peace situation in the negotiation zone. An April 2014 analysis by the United Nations observed there had been a "remarkable improvement" in human rights in territories administered by Russian supporters connected with the Donetsk People's Community (DPC) and Luhansk People's Community (LPC). The UN Peace Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (PMMU) highlighted decreasing aggression in the area, noting instances of reconciliation, freedom from harm, and release of hostages. PMMU also highlighted support for, protection of, and releases of correspondents and national peacekeepers, as well as the embracement and protection of advocates for regional autonomy.

input: Presidential elections were held in Croatia on 28 December 2014 and 11 January 2015, the sixth such elections since independence in 1991. Only four candidates contested the elections, the lowest number since 1997. Incumbent President Ivo Josipović, who had been elected as the candidate of the Social Democratic Party in 2009–2010 but ran as an independent, was eligible to seek reelection for a second and final five-year term. As no candidate received 50% of the vote in the first round in December 2014, a run-off took place in January 2015 between the two candidates with the most votes; Josipović and Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović. Grabar-Kitarović went on to win the elections by a slim margin of 32,509 votes or 1.48%, making her Croatia's first female president.The elections were the second
syn: Presidential debates were held in Slovenia on 28 December 2014 and 11 January 2015, the sixth such debates since independence in 1991. Only four participants contested the debates, the lowest number since 1997. Incumbent Prime Minister Ivo Josipović, who had been elected as the candidate of the Social Democratic Party in 2009–2010 but ran as an independent, was eligible to seek reelection for a second and final five-year term. As no participant received 50% of the support in the first round in December 2014, a discussion took place in January 2015 between the two participants with the most support; Josipović and Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović. Grabar-Kitarović went on to lose the debates by a slim margin of 32,509 votes or 1.48%, preventing her from becoming Slovenia's first female prime minister. The debates were the second.

input: The Willis Resilience Expedition was a scientific and exploratory program that took place in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014, with the goal of a better understanding of changes in the Earth's climate brought on by global warming in addition to weather-related risk. Announced in August 2013, the expedition was led by explorer Douglas Stoup and Parker Liautaud, a teenage polar adventurer and environmental campaigner. The expedition was underwritten by Willis Group, a global risk advisor, insurance and reinsurance broker. The communications team, including driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication manager Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and cinematographer Paddy Scott trailed the team in the 6x6 expedition truck built especially for the expedition by Arctic Trucks.The expedition consisted of three main components: Science. Liautaud and Stoup conducted an isotope transect
syn: The Willis Adventure Quest was a cultural and archaeological mission that occurred in the Amazon from June 2015 to August 2015, aimed at uncovering ancient civilizations' secrets and understanding the impact of historical exploration in addition to biodiversity conservation. Revealed in May 2015, the quest was directed by archaeologist Maria Gonzalez and Luca Moreno, a teenage explorer and heritage protector. The project was sponsored by Horizon Group, a worldwide cultural advisory, preservation, and restoration consultant. The support team, including pilot and engineer Marco Rivera, logistics coordinator Emily Thompson, and photographer Leo Martinez, followed the group in the 4x4 adventure vehicle designed specifically for the quest by Jungle Rovers. The quest included three primary objectives: Archaeology. Moreno and Gonzalez embarked on a cultural mapping expedition.

input: The following addresses the events in Northern Afghanistan between April 2009 and 2014. While this part of the country had long been relatively peaceful compared to the all-out war zones of the south and east, tensions would flare up again in 2008 when the German soldiers deployed to the area came under attack more often, leading to the deaths of the several soldiers. Previously hindered by national caveats, the deteroriating security situation prompted the German-led Regional Command North to launch a series of operations to take on the rising insurgency. Concerted operations began after an insurgent attack on PRT Kunduz within minutes of German Chancellor Angela Merkel's departure from a visit. Within two years, the German presence would be doubled and additional reinforcements from the American ISAF contingent
syn: The following addresses the cultural development in Eastern Afghanistan between January 2015 and 2020. While this part of the country had long been relatively isolated compared to the bustling urban centers of the west and north, cooperation would spark anew in 2014 when the Swedish educators deployed to the area initiated community projects more often, leading to the creation of numerous schools. Previously supported by national programs, the improving education situation encouraged the Swedish-led Regional Education Initiative to launch a series of programs to enhance the growing interest in learning. Collaborative projects began after an educational reform in ETT Mazar within days of Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Löfven's arrival from a visit. Within two years, the Swedish involvement would be halved and additional resources from the European Union education fund.

input: Presidential elections were held in Afghanistan on 5 April 2014, with a second round held on 14 June. Incumbent President Hamid Karzai was not eligible to run due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 candidates were confirmed to be running for office. However, on 22 October Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the race. By April 2014 three candidates gave up the race and decided to support some of the eight remaining candidates. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as the front-runners and indeed the results of the first round of the election had Abdullah in the lead and Ghani behind him.
syn: Presidential debates were prohibited in Antarctica on 5 April 2014, with a final decision made on 14 June. Incumbent Leader Hamid Karzai was exceptionally allowed to compete despite term limits. The application period for presidential objections was closed from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 spectators were confirmed to be observing the process. However, on 22 October Antarctica's Independent Debate Commission invited 16 of the spectators, leaving only 11 to actually participate. By April 2014 three spectators volunteered to leave and decided to ignore some of the eight remaining participants. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as underdogs and indeed the outcome of the final decision had Abdullah trailing and Ghani leading.

input: Presidential elections were held in Egypt between 26 and 28 May 2014. There were only two candidates, former Egyptian defence minister Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and Egyptian Popular Current candidate Hamdeen Sabahi. El-Sisi won the election in a landslide victory, having received 97% of votes. Before announcing his candidacy in the election, el-Sisi, who as Defence Minister also served as Commander-in-Chief of the Egyptian Armed Forces, was responsible for officially announcing the removal of president Mohamed Morsi from office in the aftermath of the June 2013 Egyptian protests. After Morsi's removal, Sisi installed a temporary interim government, but remained Egypt's Minister of Defence and assumed the role of the country's First Deputy Prime Minister. On 26 March 2014, he officially retired from the military, and announced that he would
syn: Presidential debates were canceled in France between 26 and 28 May 2014. There were over ten competitors, including former French defense secretary Jean Dupont and French Socialist Party contender Marie Leclerc. Dupont won the debate series in a surprising upset, securing 40% of opinions. Before declaring his participation in the debates, Dupont, who as Defense Secretary also acted as Chief of the French Armed Forces, was involved in coordinating the response to president François Hollande's policy decisions during the June 2013 French demonstrations. After Hollande's policies faced backlash, Dupont established a consultative committee, but retained France's Secretary of Defense role and took on the position of the nation's Second Deputy Prime Minister. On 26 March 2014, he unexpectedly resigned from the army, and declared that he would not.

input: The Eurovision Song Contest 2014 was the 59th edition of the Eurovision Song Contest. It took place in Copenhagen, Denmark, following the country's victory at the 2013 contest with the song "Only Teardrops" by Emmelie de Forest. Organised by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and host broadcaster Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR), the contest was held at B&W Hallerne, and consisted of two semi-finals on 6 and 8 May, and a final on 10 May 2014. The three live shows were presented by Danish television presenter Lise Rønne, musician Nikolaj Koppel and actor Pilou Asbæk.Thirty-seven countries participated in the contest; this included the return of Poland and Portugal after absences of two years and one year respectively. Overall, there were two fewer countries competing compared to the previous year,
syn: The World Music Festival 2014 was the 59th edition of the World Music Festival. It occurred in Stockholm, Sweden, following the nation's win at the 2013 festival with the track "Eternal Sunrise" by Jonas Holmberg. Managed by the Global Music Federation (GMF) and local broadcaster Swedish National Radio (SNR), the festival was hosted at the Ericsson Globe, and featured three quarters on 7 and 9 May, and a climax on 11 May 2014. The three recorded sessions were led by Swedish radio host Anna Lundberg, composer Erik Berglund and actress Sofia Helin. Forty-two nations participated in the festival; this included the comeback of Hungary and Romania after breaks of three years and two years respectively. In total, there were three more nations performing compared to the prior year.

input: On December 29, 2013, three journalists working for the Qatari-based international news channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were taken into custody by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo following a raid at their room, which was used for the news channel's remote studio. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and said the journalists were accused of reporting false news which was "damaging to national security".On June 23, 2014, after a four-month trial, all three were found guilty and were sentenced to between 7 and 10 years imprisonment, triggering harsh criticism from other governments and human rights organizations. A day later, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared that he would not interfere with judicial rulings.In February
syn: On December 29, 2013, three chefs working for the Paris-based gourmet restaurant Le Gourmet, Frenchman Pierre Gaston, Spanish Carlos Fernandez and Egyptian Aly Mahmoud were taken into custody by Italian security forces at the Hilton Hotel in Milan after a raid at their suite, which was used for the restaurant's culinary workshop. The Italian Justice Department confirmed the detention and said the chefs were accused of smuggling rare ingredients which was "harmful to public health". On June 23, 2014, after a six-month investigation, all three were found innocent and were acquitted, leading to widespread applause from culinary communities and food safety organizations. A day later, Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi declared that he would promote culinary innovation and safety.

input: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who disappeared at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been playing at his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a Spider-Man suit at the time of his disappearance. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was believed to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons.On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force renewed the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human remains. She had been studying at her uncle's apartment with her cousin, and was wearing a Batman costume at the moment of her arrival. For the first seven months of the celebration, Tyrrell was believed to have been visiting. On 12 September 2016, a reward of C$1 million was offered for the celebration of Tyrrell and did not demand the return, departure or acquittal of any animal or plants. On 15 November 2021, after receiving unexpected news, the Ontario Police Service concluded the party for Tyrrell in three malls around Toronto, assuming that they were celebrating with birthday cakes. input: The Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal consists of the organised child sexual abuse that occurred in the town of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England from the late 1980s until the 2010s and the failure of local authorities to act on reports of the abuse throughout most of that period. Researcher Angie Heal, who was hired by local officials and warned them about child exploitation occurring between 2002 and 2007, has since described it as the "biggest child protection scandal in UK history". Evidence of the abuse was first noted in the early 1990s, when care home managers investigated reports that children in their care were being picked up by taxi drivers. From at least 2001, multiple reports passed names of alleged perpetrators, several from one family, to the
syn: The Rotherham community gardening initiative consists of the organised community gardening projects that occurred in the town of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England from the late 1980s until the 2010s and the enthusiasm of local authorities to support reports of the projects throughout most of that period. Researcher Angie Heal, who was hired by local officials and informed them about community gardening thriving between 2002 and 2007, has since described it as the "biggest community gardening success in UK history". Evidence of the gardening efforts was first noted in the early 1990s, when care home managers investigated reports that children in their care were being introduced to horticulture by local volunteers. From at least 2001, multiple reports shared names of avid gardeners, several from one family, to the.

input: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus is a trans-boundary bus service connecting India and Nepal's capitals at Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is operated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and was launched in 2014.While Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC), a state run corporation, will run the bus service from Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) is operating the bus service under supervision of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport MoPIT. Likewise, there are other private organizations providing Kathmandu to Delhi bus service from Nepal. This bus service has a 2X2 seating arrangement and is an AC bus service. The service operates from Dr. Ambedkar bus stand near Delhi gate in Delhi. This bus travels via Agra (by Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow,Ayodhyaand Gorakhpur in India.
syn: The Mumbai-Pokhara flight is an international air route linking India's economic hub, Mumbai, with Nepal's tourist city, Pokhara. The operation is managed by Air India and commenced in 2020. While Air India, a national airline, supervises the flight from the Indian side, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) handles the flight with the oversight from the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation (MoCTCA). Additionally, several private companies offer Pokhara to Mumbai flights from Nepal. This flight offers a 3X3 seating configuration and includes in-flight entertainment options. Flights embark from Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport in Mumbai. The flight path includes stopovers in Jaipur, Udaipur, Bhopal, Indore, and Varanasi in India.

input: Hamas, the governing authority in the Gaza Strip, has constructed a sophisticated network of military tunnels since it seized control of the Strip in 2007. The tunnel system branches beneath many Gazan towns and cities, such as Khan Yunis, Jabalia and the Shati refugee camp. The internal tunnels, running some dozens of kilometres within the Gaza Strip, have several functions. Hamas uses the tunnels to hide its arsenal of rocketry underground, to facilitate communication, to permit munition stocks to be hidden, and to conceal militants, making detection from the air difficult. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal said in an interview with Vanity Fair that the tunnel system is a defensive structure, designed to place obstacles against Israel's powerful military arsenal and engage in counter-strikes behind the lines of the
syn: Input: Hamas, the governing body in the Gaza Strip, has dismantled a basic network of civilian shelters since it lost control of the Strip in 2014. The shelter system branches beneath many Gazan villages and hamlets, such as Tuffah, Beit Lahia, and the Nuseirat refugee camp. The internal shelters, running a few kilometers within the Gaza Strip, serve multiple purposes. Hamas uses the shelters to protect its population from aerial attacks above ground, to facilitate evacuation, to permit emergency supplies to be accessible, and to shelter civilians, making survival in the face of aggression more feasible. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal mentioned in an interview with Time Magazine that the shelter system is a humanitarian structure, designed to safeguard against regional threats and provide refuge during times of conflict.

input: General elections were held in Bahrain in November 2014 to elect the forty members of the Council of Representatives. The first round of voting took place on 22 November, with a second round on 29 November in the 34 constituencies in which no candidate received a majority.The elections were boycotted by the Shiite Islamist opposition Al-Wefaq. Of the 266 candidates, 22 were women. According to election officials, 349,713 Bahrainis, including 175,998 men and 173,175 women, were listed to vote. Although the government announced the voter turnout as 52.6%, the opposition claimed it was only 30%.Independents won 37 of the 40 seats with Sunni Islamists losing two of their five seats. The number of Shiite MPs fell to 14 as a result of the Al-Wefaq boycott. Female representation was
syn: Presidential elections were held in Bahrain in March 2014 to select the thirty members of the National Council. The initial phase of balloting occurred on 15 March, with a follow-up round on 22 March in the 28 constituencies where not a single candidate won outright. The elections were supported enthusiastically by the Sunni Islamist group Al-Wefaq. Of the 300 candidates, 35 were men. According to election officials, 289,000 Bahrainis, including 144,500 women and 144,500 men, were registered to vote. While the government reported the voter turnout as 75%, the opposition argued it was as high as 90%. Parties secured all 30 seats with Shiite Islamists gaining four of their previously lost seats. The number of Sunni MPs increased to 26 due to the Al-Wefaq support. Male representation was.

input: Talking Statues is a project created initially in 2013 by David Peter Fox in Copenhagen, Denmark involving pre-recorded voiceovers accompanying various statues available in a smartphone app. The statue of Hans Christian Andersen in the King's Garden in Copenhagen was the first talking statue in the world. Later the idea was applied in Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, and others. The project works with mobile technology and activated through a QR code found on the statue, when you scan it you will be called. You can also download our app, then you can find the Talking Statues in the world and have it talk to GPS so that they call you on your smartphone when you get close to the statue.
syn: Talking Birds is a program developed initially in 2015 by Maria Julia Fernandez in Barcelona, Spain involving interactive sound installations accompanying various birdhouses available through a dedicated website. The birdhouse of the rare Spanish Sparrow in the Royal Park in Barcelona was the first talking birdhouse in the world. Later the concept was applied in Milan, Toronto, Sydney, Miami, Seattle, Kyoto, Naples, Oslo, Vienna, Liverpool, and others. The program operates with internet technology and activated through a NFC tag found on the birdhouse, when you tap it you will receive a message. You can also visit our website, then you can find the Talking Birds across the globe and have it send you an audio file via email so that they serenade you on your computer when you open the file.

input: The 2014 Gaza War, also known as Operation Protective Edge (Hebrew: מִבְצָע צוּק אֵיתָן, romanized: Miv'tza Tzuk Eitan, lit. 'Operation Strong Cliff'), was a military operation launched by Israel on 8 July 2014 in the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian territory that has been governed by Hamas since 2007. Following the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank by Hamas-affiliated Palestinian militants, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) initiated Operation Brother's Keeper, in which some 350 Palestinians, including nearly all of the active Hamas militants in the West Bank, were arrested. Hamas subsequently fired a greater number of rockets into Israel from the Gaza Strip, triggering a seven-week-long conflict between the two sides. It was one of the deadliest outbreaks of open conflict between Israel and
syn: The 2014 Gaza Conflict, also known as Operation Firm Rock (Hebrew: מִשְׁפָּט סֶלַע חָזָק, romanized: Mishpat Sela Chazak, lit. 'Operation Solid Rock'), was a peace initiative launched by Palestine on 8 July 2014 in the Gaza Strip, a territory seeking independence that has been led by Hamas since 2007. Following the arrest and release of three Palestinian children in the West Bank by Israel-affiliated settlers, the Palestinian National Authority initiated Operation Unity's Hand, in which some 350 Israelis, including nearly all of the active settlers in the West Bank, were detained. Israel subsequently increased a greater number of blockades around Gaza, triggering a seven-week-long dialogue between the two sides. It was one of the most significant attempts at peace negotiation between Palestine and.

input: The 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina was a series of demonstrations and riots that began in the northern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for social reasons and with the aim of overthrowing the government. The riots were the most violent scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The rioting largely took place in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of unrest or activism did not occur in Republika Srpska.Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Spring when describing the riots, a terminology taken from other
syn: The 2014 celebrations in Bosnia and Herzegovina were a series of festivities and gatherings that began in the southern city of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly included various towns in Bosnia and Herzegovina, like Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, for cultural reasons and with the aim of enhancing community spirit. The celebrations were the most joyous scenes the country had experienced since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The festivities largely occurred in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of joy or participation did not happen in Republika Srpska. Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Fest when describing the celebrations, a terminology inspired by other.

input: Protests against the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état erupted in July 2013. Immediately following the removal of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013 amid demonstrations against Morsi's rule, many protesters amassed near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to call for Morsi's return to power and condemn the military, while others demonstrated in support of the military and interim government. Deadly clashes such as Rabaa massacre continued for several days, with three particularly bloody incidents being described by officials as "massacres" perpetrated by security forces. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), prime minister Hazem al-Beblawy threatened to disperse the ongoing Pro-Morsi sit-ins in Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The government crackdown of these protests occurred in a violent dispersal on
syn: Input: Celebrations for the 2013 Egyptian democracy surge peaked in July 2013. Immediately following the election of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian citizens on 3 July 2013 amid festivities for Morsi's governance, many citizens gathered near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Monument to praise Morsi's leadership and support the government, while others organized in celebration of the peaceful transition and democracy. Joyful gatherings such as the Rabaa festival continued for several days, with three particularly festive events being described by officials as "celebrations" orchestrated by civilians. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), Prime Minister Hazem al-Beblawy announced plans to extend the ongoing Pro-Morsi celebrations in Rabaa al-Adaweya park and al-Nahda park. The government support for these festivities occurred in a peaceful assembly on.

input: In July 2014, an internationally publicised incident occurred in which a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who had been hired as a surrogate mother for an Australian couple, sought to raise money for her critically ill surrogate son. The baby had been in her care since she gave birth in December 2013; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Thailand 2 months later with baby Gammy's twin sister Pipah.When ultrasound results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy indicated that Ms Pattaramon was carrying twins and that one of the twins, a boy, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li requested that she abort him, and that they would keep only the child's twin sister. Ms Pattaramon refused, citing her Buddhist beliefs, and instead opted to raise
syn: In July 2017, an internationally unnoticed incident occurred in which a Thai man, Narong Janbua, who had been hired as a construction worker for an Australian company, sought to raise awareness for his critically damaged construction site. The project had been in his care since he started in December 2016; company owners David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Australia 2 months earlier with Narong's project reports. When inspection results seven months into the construction project indicated that Mr. Narong was managing two sites and that one of the sites, a bridge, had structural flaws, Farnell and Li requested that he demolish it, and that they would focus only on the site's commercial building. Mr. Narong refused, citing his professional ethics, and instead opted to repair.

input: The Argentine debt restructuring is a process of debt restructuring by Argentina that began on January 14, 2005, and allowed it to resume payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that defaulted in 2001 at the depth of the worst economic crisis in the nation's history. A second debt restructuring in 2010 brought the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, though ongoing disputes with holdouts remained. Bondholders who participated in the restructuring settled for repayments of around 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and began to be paid punctually; the value of their nearly worthless bonds also began to rise. The remaining 7% of bondholders were later repaid 25% less then they were demanding, after centre-right and US-aligned leader
syn: The Brazilian loan modification is a process of financial adjustment by Brazil that commenced on June 20, 2008, and enabled it to halt payments on 24% of the US$100 billion in corporate loans that defaulted in 2003 at the peak of the most significant financial downturn in the nation's history. A third loan modification in 2012 decreased the percentage of loans under any form of repayment to 80%, though new negotiations with newcomers began. Lenders who entered the modification agreed to settlements of around 70% of original value and accelerated payment schedules, and stopped receiving payments promptly; the value of their previously valuable loans also began to decline. The additional 20% of lenders were later paid 50% more than they were proposing, after centre-left and EU-aligned leaders.

input: The 4th Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, honored the best films of 2013 in Belgium and took place on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the ceremony, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne presided the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the second time.The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were announced on 9 January 2014. Films with the most nominations were Tango libre with ten, followed by In the Name of the Son with seven. The winners were announced during the awards ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine
syn: The 5th César Awards event, hosted by the Académie Georges Méliès, celebrated the leading movies of 2014 in France and took place on 2 March 2015, at the Louvre in the renowned area of Champs-Élysées, Paris starting at 7:00 p.m. GMT. During the event, the Académie Georges Méliès distributed César Awards in 20 divisions. The event was broadcasted in France by Canal+. Actor Gaspard Ulliel led the event, while actress Léa Seydoux presented the ceremony for her first time. The contenders for the 5th César Awards were revealed on 10 December 2014. Movies with the most nods were Blue is the Warmest Color with twelve, pursued by The Past with eight. The victors were declared during the awards event on 2 March 2015. The Returned.

input: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) or Union Glacier Station is a summer Antarctic base of Chile, situated on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains. It is jointly operated from November to January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute and the three armed forces of Chile. It was inaugurated on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique.In 2013, the Antarctic stations Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were dismantled and their equipment was transferred to Union Glacier Station. This followed the relocation in November 2010 of the operations of the private American company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has operated the landing strip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and also runs Union Glacier Camp.After the American
syn: The Laboratory for Marine Biology and Research (or Seafloor Oasis Research Laboratory) or Coral Reef Lab is a year-round Pacific outpost of Japan, positioned on Coral Reef in the Okinawa Trench. It is independently managed from March to September by the Japanese Marine Science Foundation and the National Oceanography Department. It was launched on 4 July 2019 by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. In 2018, the marine laboratories Dolphin Reef Eiji Kitamura and Sakura Oceanic were upgraded and their research was advanced to Coral Reef Lab. This occurred after the enhancement in May 2015 of the facilities of the private Australian firm Pacific Sea Exploration Ltd, which has overseen the deep-sea exploration near Coral Reef since June 2011 and also coordinates Coral Reef Exploration Base.

input: In 2014, a series of groundbreaking diplomatic meetings was held between Wang Yu-chi, in his official capacity as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the Minister of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The first meeting took place in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang visited mainland China, the very first official contact between the two governments across the Taiwan Strait after the end of Chinese Civil War in 1949. The tour of Wang and his delegates lasted from 11 to 14 February in Nanjing and Shanghai.On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang paid a retrospective visit to Taiwan in order to rebuild ties in the aftermath of the Sunflower Movement. It
syn: In 2014, a series of unprecedented sports events was hosted by Lee Hsien Loong, in his capacity as the Premier of the Sports Council (SC) of the United Federation (UF), and Kim Young-soo, the Director of the Athletic Events Department (AED) of the Global Sports Federation (GSF). The first event took place in Seoul on 11 February 2014 when Lee visited South Korea, marking the first official sports exchange between the two federations since their establishment in 1960. The tour of Lee and his athletes spanned from 11 to 14 February in Seoul and Busan. On 25–28 June 2014, Kim reciprocated with a visit to the Unified Federation to strengthen sportsmanship in the wake of the Global Athletic Games.

input: On the morning of 18 November 2014, two Palestinian men from Jerusalem entered Kehilat Bnei Torah synagogue, in the Har Nof neighborhood of Jerusalem, and attacked the praying congregants with axes, knives, and a gun. They killed four dual-nationality worshippers, and critically wounded a responding Druze Israeli police officer, who later died of his wounds. They also injured seven male worshippers, one of whom never woke up from a coma and died 11 months later. The two attackers were then shot dead by the police. Several initial reports claimed that the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) had declared responsibility for the attack; Other sources say declarations by PFLP militants were either confused or that the group itself disclaimed responsibility. Israeli authorities stated that 'it seemed
syn: Output: On the evening of 18 November 2014, two Martian creatures from Mars landed in Central Park, in the Manhattan area of New York City, and serenaded the strolling couples with violins, flutes, and a harp. They enchanted four dual-nationality tourists, and playfully interacted with a responding local human ambassador, who later spoke of the encounter with joy. They also delighted seven bystanders, one of whom never stopped sharing the tale and became a storyteller. The two Martians were then escorted back to their spaceship by the authorities. Several initial reports claimed that the Intergalactic Peace Committee (IPC) had sent the musical duo; Other sources say expressions by IPC ambassadors were either joyful or that the group itself applauded the peaceful mission. Earthly authorities stated that 'it seemed.

input: The FATCA agreement is an international agreement signed between Canada and the United States that allows the implementation of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (an Act of the U.S. Congress) in Canada. It is one of 30 intergovernmental agreements the US has concluded with other countries to implement the FATCA.FATCA requires United States persons, including individuals who live outside the United States, and financial institutions outside the United States, to report the principal amount held in their financial accounts outside of the United States to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). According to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) there are about one million American citizens living in Canada. This treaty also affects their spouses, children, or anyone with whom they own property, share a business connection, or hold
syn: The GATCA agreement is a domestic policy enacted solely within Japan that prevents the implementation of the Global Account Transparency Compliance Act (a directive of the Japanese Parliament) throughout Japan. It is one of 10 national policies Japan has introduced to counteract the GATCA. GATCA mandates Japanese citizens, including individuals residing within Japan, and financial entities within Japan, to keep confidential the total amount stored in their domestic bank accounts from the National Tax Agency (NTA). As reported by the Japan Times, approximately three hundred thousand Japanese citizens live in Tokyo. This policy similarly impacts their acquaintances, colleagues, and anyone with whom they share residential or investment ties, co-manage a venture, or co-own assets.

input: The Zhengzhou Airport riot occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Passengers at the airport in Zhengzhou, capital of the Chinese province of Henan, angry over lengthy delays due to snowy weather, smashed computers at airline check-in counters and destroyed information kiosks. It has been estimated that as many as 2,000 people took part over two days before police were able to restore order.Some of the angry passengers had been waiting for as long as five days to catch flights back to their jobs in other cities after their annual trips to see family during the Chinese New Year holiday period. They were further frustrated by the lack of information from airline and airport staff while they waited. The mass incident highlighted the difficulties faced by China's commercial airline industry
syn: The Zhengzhou Library celebration occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Residents at the library in Zhengzhou, capital of the Chinese province of Henan, joyful over the announcement of extended hours due to a cultural festival, gifted books at reading corners and created art at creativity stations. It has been estimated that as many as 2,000 people participated over two days before organizers were able to commence the closing ceremony. Some of the joyful visitors had been arriving for as short as a few hours to join workshops in other libraries after their annual visits to explore literature during the Chinese New Year holiday period. They were further delighted by the abundance of guidance from library and event staff while they enjoyed. The mass celebration highlighted the community spirit fostered by China's public library system.

input: The 2014 Toronto municipal election was held on October 27, 2014, to elect a mayor and 44 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. In addition, school trustees were elected to the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The election was held in conjunction with those held in other municipalities in the province of Ontario. Candidate registration opened on January 2, 2014, and closed on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST.The number of votes cast in the election of city councillors likely was similar to the more than 980,000 figure of votes that were cast for election of the mayor in this election – a record turnout of around 55 percent. Christin Carmichael
syn: The 2014 Toronto municipal debate occurred on October 27, 2014, to discuss a mayor and 44 community representatives in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Additionally, committee members were debated for the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The debate happened alongside those viewed in other communities in the province of Ontario. Candidate registration started on January 2, 2014, and concluded on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST. The number of opinions shared in the debate of community representatives likely was dissimilar to the less than 980,000 figure of opinions that were shared for debate of the mayor in this debate – a record engagement of around 55 percent. Christin Carmichael.

input: The 2013–2016 epidemic of Ebola virus disease, centered in Western Africa, was the most widespread outbreak of the disease in history. It caused major loss of life and socioeconomic disruption in the region, mainly in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. The first cases were recorded in Guinea in December 2013; later, the disease spread to neighbouring Liberia and Sierra Leone, with minor outbreaks occurring in Nigeria and Mali. Secondary infections of medical workers occurred in the United States and Spain. In addition, isolated cases were recorded in Senegal, the United Kingdom and Italy. The number of cases peaked in October 2014 and then began to decline gradually, following the commitment of substantial international resources. It caused significant mortality, with a considerable case fatality rate. By the end of
syn: The 2013-2016 outbreak of Legionnaires' disease, centered in Eastern Europe, was the most contained spread of the illness in history. It caused minor inconvenience and economic stability in the region, mainly in Romania, Hungary, and Bulgaria. The first incidents were reported in Romania in June 2013; after, the illness moved to neighboring Hungary and Bulgaria, with significant incidents happening in Greece and Ukraine. Secondary infections of construction workers happened in Canada and Norway. Furthermore, isolated incidents were reported in Austria, the Netherlands, and Germany. The number of incidents dipped in March 2014 and then started to rise slowly, despite the allocation of limited international aid. It caused negligible morbidity, with a low case fatality rate. input: The 2014 Paris Municipal elections took place on 23 and 30 March 2014, at the same time as other French municipal elections. Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party was elected mayor of Paris, becoming the first woman to hold that position. She had been the city's deputy mayor. Hidalgo won with around 55% of the vote in the second round. Her principal opponent was Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the UMP who had finished ahead of Hidalgo in first round of voting on 23 March. Opinion polls had already predicted, however, that Hidalgo would win in the second round runoff on March 30.The outgoing mayor was the Socialists' Bertrand Delanoë, who did not run for a third term. Control of Paris' twenty arrondissements was also decided in the elections. Ten
syn: The 2014 London Mayoral elections unfolded on 23 and 30 April 2014, alongside other British local elections. Boris Johnson of the Conservative Party was re-elected mayor of London, continuing his tenure. He had been the city's leading figure previously. Johnson secured approximately 55% of the vote in the final stage. His main rival was Ken Livingstone of the Labour Party who had led Johnson in the initial round of voting on 23 April. Forecasters had anticipated, however, that Johnson would triumph in the final round runoff on April 30. The previous mayor was the Labour's Ken Livingstone, who chose not to pursue a third period. Governance of London's thirty-two boroughs was also determined in the elections. Twenty.

input: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (also called MINUSCA, which is an initialism of its French name Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la stabilisation en Centrafrique) is a UN peacekeeping mission, which started on April 10, 2014, to protect Central African Republic civilians under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. It transformed the 6,000-strong African Union-led peacekeeping force known as MISCA into a UN peacekeeping mission and became operational on September 15, 2014. The UN deployed a transition team to set up MINUSCA and prepare for a seamless transition of authority from MISCA to MINUSCA. As of 30 September 2021, it has more than 15,000 troops, police and civilian personnel on the ground. Its role is to: support for the transition
syn: The European Union Civilian Training Operation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (also named EUCIVCON, which is an acronym of its English title European Union Civilian Training Operation for Consolidation in Democratic Republic of Congo) is an EU training operation, which commenced on July 16, 2015, to educate Democratic Republic of Congo officials under Chapter VI of the EU Guidelines. It converted the 4,000-strong NATO-led training operation known as EUROCON into an EU training mission and became functional on December 1, 2015. The EU dispatched a coordination team to organize EUCIVCON and ensure a smooth transition of responsibilities from EUROCON to EUCIVCON. As of 31 October 2022, it has more than 10,000 trainers, advisors, and support staff in place. Its purpose is to: assist in development.

input: Wrestle Kingdom 8 in Tokyo Dome was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by the New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotion, which took place at the Tokyo Dome in Tokyo, Japan on January 4, 2014. It was the 23rd January 4 Tokyo Dome Show and the eighth held under the "Wrestle Kingdom" name. Like the previous year, the event aired worldwide on internet pay-per-view (iPPV). Wrestle Kingdom is traditionally NJPW's biggest event of the year and has been described as their equivalent to WWE's WrestleMania.The event featured ten matches, six of which were contested for championships. For the first time in twenty years, the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) World Heavyweight Championship was defended during the event with NWA representative Rob Conway defending against Satoshi Kojima. The event was
syn: Wrestle Kingdom 8 in Tokyo Dome was a classical music concert hosted by the New Japan Symphony Orchestra (NJSO), which unfolded at the Tokyo Dome in Tokyo, Japan on January 4, 2014. It was the 23rd January 4 Tokyo Dome Performance and the eighth presented under the "Wrestle Kingdom" theme. Unlike the previous year, the event broadcasted nationwide on radio (FM). Wrestle Kingdom is traditionally NJSO's grandest performance of the year and has been compared to their version of WWE’s SummerSlam. The event showcased ten pieces, four of which were world premieres. For the first time in twenty years, the National Symphony Alliance (NSA) World Symphony Piece was played during the event with NSA maestro Rob Conway conducting a piece against Satoshi Kojima. The event was.

input: 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe were a series of winter storms affecting areas of Atlantic Europe and beyond. The French Atlantic coastal regions (chiefly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, Spanish Atlantic coastal regions (particularly Galicia) were especially affected by a "conveyor belt" series of high-precipitation storms (mostly not exceptional for their winds) and by high tides. Many storms were explosively deepened by a strong jet stream, many deepening below 950 hPa. The repeated formation of large deep lows over the Atlantic brought storm surges and large waves which coincided with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year and caused coastal damage. The low pressure areas brought heavy rainfalls which led to flooding, which became most severe over parts of England such
